{{Use dmy dates|date=July 2012}} {{Infobox football biography | name = Luciano Galletti | image = [[File:Luciano Galletti, 2009.jpg|200px]] | caption = Galletti in 2009 | fullname = Luciano Martín Galletti | birth_date = {{Birth date and age|1980|4|9|df=yes}} | birth_place = [[La Plata]], [[Argentina]] | height = {{height|meter=1.75}} | position = [[Midfielder#Winger|Winger]] | currentclub = | youthyears1 = 1991–1993 | youthclubs1 = Tolosano | youthyears2 = 1993–1997 | youthclubs2 = [[Estudiantes de La Plata|Estudiantes]] | years1 = 1997–1999 | clubs1 = [[Estudiantes de La Plata|Estudiantes]] | caps1 = 37 | goals1 = 2 | years2 = 1999 | clubs2 = [[Parma F.C.|Parma]] | caps2 = 0 | goals2 = 0 | years3 = 1999–2000 | clubs3 = [[S.S.C. Napoli|Napoli]] | caps3 = 20 | goals3 = 2 | years4 = 2000–2001 | clubs4 = [[Estudiantes de La Plata|Estudiantes]] | caps4 = 28 | goals4 = 9 | years5 = 2001–2005 | clubs5 = [[Real Zaragoza|Zaragoza]] | caps5 = 134 | goals5 = 14 | years6 = 2005–2007 | clubs6 = [[Atlético Madrid]] | caps6 = 62 | goals6 = 5 | years7 = 2007–2010 | clubs7 = [[Olympiacos F.C.|Olympiacos]] | caps7 = 59 | goals7 = 19 | years8 = 2013 | clubs8 = [[OFI Crete F.C.|OFI]] | caps8 = 6 | goals8 = 0 | totalcaps = 346 |totalgoals = 51 | nationalyears1 = 1999 | nationalteam1 = [[Argentina national under-20 football team|Argentina U20]] | nationalcaps1 = 12 | nationalgoals1 = 10 | nationalyears2 = 2000–2005 | nationalteam2 = [[Argentina national football team|Argentina]] | nationalcaps2 = 13 | nationalgoals2 = 3 | club-update = | nationalteam-update = }} '''Luciano Martín Galletti''' ({{IPA-es|luˈsjano ɣaˈleti}}; born 9 April 1980) is an Argentine retired [[Association football|footballer]] who played as a [[Midfielder#Winger|right winger]].
In a professional career that lasted 14 years he played mostly in Spain, with [[Real Zaragoza|Zaragoza]] and [[Atlético Madrid]], but also represented [[Olympiacos F.C.|Olympiacos]], winning five major titles with the latter club. He was also retired from 2010 to 2013, before returning to active with [[OFI Crete F.C.|OFI Crete]].
An [[Argentina national football team|Argentina international]] in the 2000s, Galletti appeared with the national team at the [[2005 FIFA Confederations Cup|2005 Confederations Cup]].
==Club career== ===Early years / Italy=== Born in [[La Plata]], [[Buenos Aires Province]], Galletti's career began with [[Estudiantes de La Plata]], where his father [[Rubén Horacio Galletti|Rubén Horacio]] played as a right-wing [[Forward (association football)|forward]] during the 1970s.<ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.clarin.com/deportes/galletti-padre-hijo-servicio-gol_0_B1Afn0weCKe.html|title=Los Galletti, padre e hijo al servicio del gol|trans-title=The Gallettis, father and son at the service of goal|newspaper=[[Clarín (Argentine newspaper)|Clarín]]|language=Spanish|date=18 June 2001|accessdate=14 December 2017}}</ref><ref name=VAVEL>{{cite web|url=https://www.vavel.com/es/futbol/real-zaragoza/205114.html|title=Yo jugué en el Real Zaragoza: Luciano Galletti|trans-title=I played for Real Zaragoza: Luciano Galletti|publisher=[[Vavel]]|language=Spanish|date=24 December 2012|accessdate=14 December 2017}}</ref> He scored once in 24 games in [[1998–99 Argentine Primera División|his second season]] in the [[Argentine Primera División|Primera División]].
In January 1999, Galletti joined [[Parma F.C.|Parma A.C.]] in [[Italy]],<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www2.raisport.rai.it/news/rubriche/cmercato/199811/11/3649c67404c65/|title=Galletti al Parma|trans-title=Galletti to Parma|publisher=[[Rai Sport 2]]|language=Italian|date=11 November 1998|accessdate=14 December 2017}}</ref> but failed to break into the first team, moving in the following [[transfer window]] to another club in the country, [[Serie B]]'s [[S.S.C. Napoli]] – loaned by Estudiantes, to where he would return for the [[2000–01 Argentine Primera División|2000–01 campaign]].
===Zaragoza=== Galletti signed with [[Real Zaragoza]] from [[Spain]] in the 2001 off-season. He made his [[La Liga]] debut on 26 August in a 1–2 away loss against [[RCD Espanyol]],<ref>{{cite news|url=https://elpais.com/diario/2001/08/27/deportes/998863222_850215.html|title=El Espanyol repite triunfo en el debú ante el Zaragoza|trans-title=Espanyol repeat win in debut against Zaragoza|newspaper=[[El País]]|language=es|date=27 August 2001|accessdate=14 December 2017}}</ref> and finished [[2001–02 La Liga|his first year]] with 27 matches and two goals as the season ended in relegation.
From there onwards, Galletti became an undisputed starter for the [[Aragon]]ese, never appearing in less than 34 contests for the remainder of his spell.<ref name=VAVEL/> In [[2003–04 La Liga|2003–04]] he helped them [[2003–04 Copa del Rey|win]] the [[Copa del Rey]], scoring the winner in a 3–2 [[Overtime (sports)|extra time]] win over [[Real Madrid C.F.|Real Madrid]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport2/hi/football/europe/3516028.stm|title=Beckham misses out on Cup|publisher=[[BBC Sport]]|date=17 March 2004|accessdate=9 August 2012}}</ref>
===Atlético Madrid=== On 29 July 2005, Galletti joined fellow league side [[Atlético Madrid]] for [[Euro|€]]4 million.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.uefa.com/memberassociations/news/newsid=321952.html|title=Galletti arrives at Atlético|publisher=UEFA|date=29 July 2005|accessdate=26 July 2007}}</ref> He netted his first league goal for his new team on 27 October, closing the scoresheet at home against [[Cádiz CF]] (3–0).<ref>{{cite web|url=http://soccernet.espn.go.com/report/_/id/190177?cc=5739|title=Atlético Madrid 3–0 Cádiz|publisher=[[ESPN FC|ESPN Soccernet]]|date=27 October 2005|accessdate=9 August 2012}}</ref>
In [[2006–07 La Liga|his second season]] with the ''Colchoneros'', Galletti scored four goals in 36 games as they finished in seventh position.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.estoesatleti.es/2017/05/que-fue-de-21-galletti/|title=Qué fue de… 21. Galletti|trans-title=What happened to… 21. Galletti|publisher=Esto es Atleti|language=Spanish|date=16 May 2017|accessdate=14 December 2017}}</ref>
===Olympiacos=== On 30 June 2007, Galletti was transferred to [[Olympiacos F.C.]] in [[Greece]], for a reported fee of €2.5m,<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.uefa.com/uefachampionsleague/news/newsid=556913.html|title=Galletti lured by European goal|publisher=UEFA|date=30 June 2007|accessdate=26 July 2007}}</ref> with the player signing a four-year contract with an annual salary of €1.3 million. On 2 May 2009 he netted the 4–4 equalizer against [[AEK Athens F.C.]] in [[2008–09 Greek Cup|the final]] of the [[Greek Football Cup|Greek Cup]], in another eventual extra time success;<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.fifa.com/worldfootball/clubfootball/news/newsid=1054264.html|title=Olympiakos win Cup in shoot-out|publisher=FIFA|date=2 May 2009|accessdate=9 August 2012}}</ref> after [[2008–09 Superleague Greece|that campaign]] ended and he contributed with a career-best 14 goals to the [[Superleague Greece|national championship]]'s conquest, he signed a contract extension linking him to the [[Piraeus]] club until 2013 – the new deal contained a release clause fee of €15million.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.olympiacos.org/index.html?#/Article/26063/|script-title=el:Ερυθρόλευκος για πάντα ο Γκαλέτι|trans-title=Galletti forever red|publisher=Olympiacos F.C|language=Greek|date=8 July 2009|accessdate=9 July 2009|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20090802182450/http://www.olympiacos.org/index.html#/Article/26063/|archivedate=2 August 2009|df=dmy-all}}</ref>
In early February 2010, Galletti was diagnosed with severe [[Renal failure|kidney failure]], causing him to miss the rest of [[2009–10 Superleague Greece|the season]]. He announced his retirement the following summer, aged only 30;<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.infobae.com/2010/09/27/538576-una-insuficiencia-renal-obligo-galletti-dejar-el-futbol-profesional/|title=Una insuficiencia renal obligó a Galletti a dejar el fútbol profesional|trans-title=Kidney failure forced Galletti to retire from professional football|publisher=[[Infobae]]|language=Spanish|date=27 September 2010|accessdate=14 December 2017}}</ref> in early October 2012, however, he underwent a successful [[Kidney transplantation|kidney transplant]], the donor being his father Rubén.<ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.lacapital.com.ar/informacion-gral/trasplantan-exito-luciano-galletti-un-rinon-del-padre-n365792.html|title=Trasplantan con éxito a Luciano Galletti un riñón del padre|trans-title=Luciano Galletti receives kidney from father in successful surgery|newspaper=[[La Capital]]|language=Spanish|date=3 October 2012|accessdate=14 December 2017}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.clarin.com/deportes/Galletti-alta-medica-dias_0_786521623.html|title=Galletti tendría el alta médica en tres días|trans-title=Galletti could be released in three days|newspaper=Clarín|language=Spanish|date=5 October 2012|accessdate=6 October 2012}}</ref>
Galletti returned to Olympiacos on 3 September 2014 after an unassuming spell as player at [[OFI Crete F.C.|OFI Crete FC]], being appointed [[Scout (sport)|scout]] for [[Latin America]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.olympiacos.org/article/40341/pae-olympiakos-anakoinosi|script-title=el:Ανακοίνωση της ΠΑΕ Ολυμπιακός σχετικά με την ένταξη του Λουτσιάνο Γκαλέτι στο τεχνικό τιμ|trans-title=Olympiacos FC announcement on Luciano Galletti's coaching integration|publisher=Olympiacos F.C|language=Greek|date=3 September 2014|accessdate=3 September 2014}}</ref>
==International career== Galletti was the top scorer at the [[1999 South American Youth Championship]] with nine goals in only eight games, ranking ahead the likes of [[Ronaldinho]] and [[Roque Santa Cruz]] as the [[Argentina national under-20 football team|Argentina under-20s]] won the competition in [[Paraguay]].<ref name=VAVEL/> He earned 13 [[Cap (sport)|caps]] for the [[Argentina national football team|full side]],<ref>{{cite news|url=http://mundod.lavoz.com.ar/futbol/padres-e-hijos-que-jugaron-para-la-seleccion-argentina|title=Padres e hijos que jugaron para la selección argentina|trans-title=Fathers and sons who played for the Argentine national team|newspaper=[[La Voz del Interior]]|language=Spanish|date=8 September 2018|accessdate=29 October 2018}}</ref> making his debut in 2000 and being selected to the squad that appeared in the [[2005 FIFA Confederations Cup]], where he played three matches for the eventual runners-up, including [[2005 FIFA Confederations Cup Final|the final]] against [[Brazil national football team|Brazil]].
==Honours== ===Club=== '''Zaragoza''' *[[Copa del Rey]]: [[2003–04 Copa del Rey|2003–04]] *[[Supercopa de España]]: [[2004 Supercopa de España|2004]]
'''Olympiacos''' *[[Superleague Greece]]: [[2007–08 Superleague Greece|2007–08]], [[2008–09 Superleague Greece|2008–09]] *[[Greek Football Cup]]: [[2007–08 Greek Cup|2007–08]], [[2008–09 Greek Cup|2008–09]] *[[Greek Super Cup]]: 2007
===International=== '''Argentina''' *[[South American Youth Championship]]: [[1999 South American Youth Championship|1999]] *[[FIFA Confederations Cup]]: Runner-up [[2005 FIFA Confederations Cup|2005]]
===Individual=== *[[South American Youth Championship]]: Top Scorer [[1999 South American Youth Championship|1999]] *[[Superleague Greece]]: [[List of top goalscorers in Superleague Greece by season|Top Scorer]] [[2008–09 Superleague Greece|2008–09]]

{{Infobox person | name = Léger-Félicité Sonthonax | image = Sonthonax.jpg | alt = | caption = Late 18th-century oil painting portrait of Sonthonax | birth_name = | birth_date = {{Birth date|1763|03|07}} | birth_place = [[Oyonnax]], [[France]] | death_date = {{Death date and age|1813|07|23|1763|03|07}} | death_place = Oyonnax, France | nationality = [[France|French]] | other_names = | occupation = [[Abolitionism in France|Abolitionist]] | years_active = | known_for = | notable_works = }} '''Léger-Félicité Sonthonax''' (7 March 1763 – 23 July 1813) was a [[France|French]] [[Abolitionism in France|abolitionist]] and [[Jacobin]] before joining the [[Girondins|Girondist]] party, which emerged in 1791. During the [[French Revolution]], he controlled 7,000 French troops in [[Saint-Domingue]] during part of the [[Haitian Revolution]].<ref>{{cite book | first=Robert | last=Stein | title=Leger Felicite Sonthonax: The Lost Sentinel of the Republic | location=Rutherford | publisher=Fairleigh Dickinson Univ Press | year=1985 | isbn=0-8386-3218-1}}</ref> His official title was Civil Commissioner. From September 1792 to December 1795, he was the ''[[de facto]]'' ruler of Saint-Domingue's non-slave populace. Within a year of his appointment, his powers were considerably expanded by the [[Committee of Public Safety]]. He was recalled in 1795 largely due to the resurgence of conservative politics in France. Sonthonax believed that Saint-Domingue's whites were [[royalist]]s or [[separatist]]s, so he attacked the military power of the white settlers and by doing so alienated the [[Colonisation|colonial]] settlers from their government. Many ''[[gens de couleur]]'' (mixed-race residents of the colony) asserted that they could form the military backbone of Saint-Domingue if they were given rights, but Sonthonax rejected this view as outdated in the wake of the August 1791 slave uprising. He believed that Saint-Domingue would need ex-slave soldiers among the ranks of the colonial army if it was to survive. On August 1793, he proclaimed freedom for all slaves in the north province. His critics allege that he was forced into ending slavery in order to maintain his own power.<ref>{{cite book | first=Jan | last=Rogozinski | year= 1999 | title= A Brief History of the Caribbean | edition= Revised | publisher=Facts on File, Inc. | location=New York | pages= 167–168 | isbn= 0-8160-3811-2 }}</ref>
==Early life== Born in [[Oyonnax]], [[France]] on March 7, 1763, the son of a prosperous merchant, Sonthonax was a [[lawyer]] in the [[Parlement]] of [[Paris]] who rose in the ranks during the [[French Revolution]]. Sonthonax's wealth was due to his father's trade market, which had many employees from his village.<ref name=":1">{{Cite web|url=http://www.ghcaraibe.org/bul/ghc020/p0204.html|title=G.H.C. Bulletin 20 : Octobre 1990 Page 204|website=www.ghcaraibe.org|access-date=2017-02-26}}</ref> Sonthonax finished his studies at the [[University of Burgundy|University of Dijon]], becoming a well-known lawyer with the help of his wealthy father.<ref name=":1" /> A member of the [[Society of the Friends of the Blacks]], he became connected with [[Jacques Pierre Brissot]] and subsequently aligned himself with the [[Girondist]]s.
==Mission== In August 1791, a [[slave rebellion]] (the [[Haitian Revolution]]) broke out in the [[Nord (Haitian department)|northern part]] of Saint-Domingue, the heart of the island's sugar [[plantation economy]]. Saint-Domingue was also wracked by conflict between the [[White (people)|white]] colonists and free people of colour (many of whom were of mixed race), and also between those supportive of the French Revolution and those for a re-establishment of the [[Ancien Régime]] — or failing that, for Saint-Domingue's independence.
In 1792, Sonthonax and [[Étienne Polverel|Etienne Polverel]] were sent to the colony of Saint-Domingue (now [[Haïti]]) as part of the Revolutionary Commission. His main goal was to maintain French control of Saint-Domingue and enforce the [[social equality]] recently granted to free ''gens de couleur'' by the French [[National Convention]] as part of the decree of 4 April 1792. The legislation re-established French control of Saint-Domingue, granted full citizenship and political equality to free blacks and free mulattoes, but did not emancipate the slaves, and induced the slaves to return to the plantations. Sonthonax's mission was not to free the slaves of Saint-Domingue, but rather to enforce the decree and to defeat slave rebellions. Sonthonax had initially decried the abolition of slavery to gain the support of the whites on the island. Upon his arrival, he found that some whites and free people of color were already cooperating against the slave rebels. He did exile many radical whites who would not accept free coloreds as equals and managed to contain the slave insurgency outside of the North.
When [[Sonthonax]] and French Colonial Commissioner, [[Étienne Polverel|Etienne Polveral]], were sent to [[Saint-Domingue]], a Proclamation was made by the two. This proclamation started off granting specific freedoms to the slaves, but ultimately, slaves in the north and west of [[Saint-Domingue]] were granted freedom.<ref name=":0">{{Cite news|url=https://www.wdl.org/en/item/14722/|title=Proclamation. In the Name of the Republic. We, Etienne Polverel and Léger-Félicité Sonthonax, Civil Officers of the Republic, Whom the French Nation Sent to this Country to Establish Law and Order|date=1793-05-05|access-date=2017-02-21|language=en}}</ref> Following the proclamation, Sonthonax wrote a reply to those that were opposed to his and [[Polverel|Polveral]]'s decision in 1793 to grant these select slaves this new freedom. He declares his never ending belief that [[civil rights]] should be granted to these Africans and defends his decision to free the slaves was not [http://www.dictionary.com/browse/erroneous erroneous] to do.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://college.cengage.com/history/world/keen/latin_america/8e/assets/students/sources/pdfs/32_leger-felicite_sonthonax_decree.pdf|title=Sonthonax Broadside (1793)|last=Abidor|first=Mitch|date=2004|website=marxists.org|access-date=}}</ref> Sonthonax's ''Proclamation Au nom de la République'' explained his role in the Revolution. He was committed to make drastic decisions to prevent Britain and Spain from trying to take control of Saint-Domingue.
==Conflict with Britain and abolition== In February 1793 France [[Campaigns of 1793 in the French Revolutionary Wars|declared war]] on the [[Kingdom of Great Britain]], which presented a new problem for Sonthonax. All those he had alienated in trying to uphold the French Revolution in Saint-Domingue could now flock to the banner of Britain, which held the nearby island of [[Jamaica]] and was giving shelter to French counter-revolutionary [[émigré]]s. The white population declined significantly until only 6,000 remained after June 1793.
On 20 June 1793 a failed attempt to take control of the capital by a new military governor sympathetic to whites, Francois-Thomas Galbaud, led to the bombardment and burning of Cap-Français (now [[Cap-Haïtien]]). On June 24, 1793, 60% of the white population left Saint-Domingue with Galbaud, most never to return. Responsibility for the burning is uncertain, though it was likely done by the roughly 1,000 non-native sailors among Galbaud's forces. Up to this point the commissioners had still been pursuing the fight against the black slaves, whose insurrection had begun in August 1791, but Galbaud's attack led them to seek support from some of the black insurgent leaders in the region. The price for this was a promise of freedom for ex-slaves who agreed to fight on behalf of the commissioners and the French republican regime they represented. This emancipation was a momentous victory for all slave forces, and oral histories suggest a boost in their morale.
On August 29,1793, with rumors of emancipation rampant, Sonthonax took the radical step of proclaiming the freedom of the slaves in the north province (with severe limits on their freedom). It was during this time, and due to the new trend of conceding rights to blacks, that [[Toussaint Louverture]] began reforming his political philosophy to embrace France rather than Spain; however, he was cautious and awaited French ratification of emancipation before officially changing sides. In September and October, emancipation was extended throughout the colony. On February 4, 1794, the French National Convention ratified this act, applying it to all French colonies, including [[History of Guadeloupe|Guadeloupe]]. Emancipation was one of the most momentous events in the history of the Americas.
The slaves did not immediately join Sonthonax's side, however. White colonists continued to fight Sonthonax, with assistance from the British. They were joined by many of the free men of color who opposed the abolition of slavery. It was not until word of France's ratification of emancipation arrived back in the colony that [[Toussaint Louverture]] and his corps of well-disciplined, battle-hardened former slaves came over to the French Republican side in early May 1794.
A change in the political winds back home caused Sonthonax to be recalled to France to defend his actions. When he returned in the summer of 1794, he argued that the free people of colour, whom he had been originally sent to defend, were no longer loyal to France, and that the Republic should place its faith in the freed slaves. Vindicated, Sonthonax returned to Saint-Domingue a second time. The [[Comte d'Hédouville]] was sent by France to be governor of the island, but was eventually forced to flee.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.webster.edu/~corbetre/haiti/history/revolution/revolution3.htm |title=The Haitian Revolution, Part III |publisher= |accessdate= |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20070703210325/http://www.webster.edu/~corbetre/haiti/history/revolution/revolution3.htm |archivedate=2007-07-03 |df= }}</ref>
==Death and legacy== Toussaint, in the meantime, was consolidating his own position. The black general arranged for Sonthonax to leave Saint-Domingue as one of its elected representatives in 1797, and when Sonthonax showed himself to be hesitant, Toussaint placed him under armed escort onto a ship bound for France on 24 August. He died in his home town 16 years later.
Léger-Félicité Sonthonax is a controversial figure of the [[Haitian Revolution]]. His critics (Toussaint, [[Jean-Jacques Dessalines]] or [[André Rigaud]]) have denounced him as being vain, power-hungry and duplicitous. [[Thomas Madiou]], one of Haïti's most famous historians, writing in the middle of the 19th century deduced that his ultimate goal was to become Governor General of the island, autonomous from France and Napoleon Bonaparte, this was thus the reason why General Toussaint exiled him back to France. Toussaint felt that Sonthonax was using their plight to further his own agenda (power grab). Sonthonax is considered a controversial figure in Haitian history because of his alleged duplicitous nature. His intentions were never clear and he was not trusted by the black population{{Citation needed|date=June 2017}}. Sonthonax is seldom spoken of in Haiti today.

{{EngvarB|date=October 2013}} {{Use dmy dates|date=October 2013}} [[Image:Marion Terry.jpg|thumb|right|250px|Marion Terry]] '''Marion Bessie Terry''' (13 October 1853 – 21 August 1930) was an English actress. In a career spanning half a century, she played leading roles in more than 125 plays.<ref>[http://www.time.com/time/magazine/article/0,9171,740213-2,00.html Obituary] ''Time Magazine'', 1 September 1930</ref> Always in the shadow of her older and more famous sister [[Ellen Terry|Ellen]], Terry nevertheless achieved considerable success in the plays of [[W. S. Gilbert]], [[Oscar Wilde]], [[Henry James]] and others.
==Biography== Terry was born in England, into a theatrical family. Her birth name was '''Mary Ann Bessy Terry''', and she was nicknamed "Polly".<ref name=DNB>Booth, Michael R. [http://www.oxforddnb.com/view/article/38758, "Terry, Marion Bessie (1853–1930)",] ''Oxford Dictionary of National Biography'', Oxford University Press (2004), accessed 7 January 2010</ref> Her parents, Benjamin (1818–1896), of Irish descent, and Sarah (née Ballard) (1819–1892), of Scottish ancestry, were comic actors in a touring company based in [[Portsmouth]]<ref name=SB>[http://www.stagebeauty.net/th-frames.html?http&&&www.stagebeauty.net/terry/terry-e2.html Biography of Ellen Terry at the Stage Beauty website]</ref> (where Sarah's father was a Wesleyan minister) and had eleven children. At least five of these became actors: [[Kate Terry|Kate]], [[Ellen Terry|Ellen]], Marion, Florence and [[Fred Terry|Fred]].<ref>Booth, Michael R. [http://www.oxforddnb.com/view/article/36460 "Terry, Dame Ellen Alice (1847–1928)",] ''Oxford Dictionary of National Biography'', Oxford University Press, September 2004; online edn, January 2008, accessed 4 January 2010</ref> Two other children, George and Charles, were connected with theatre management.<ref>Hartnoll, pp. 815–17.</ref>
Terry's sister Kate was a very successful actress until her marriage and retirement from the stage in 1867, and her sister Ellen became the greatest Shakespearean actress of her time. Her great nephew (Kate's grandson), Sir [[John Gielgud]], became one of the twentieth century's most respected actors.<ref name=Answers>[http://www.answers.com/topic/ellen-terry Terry Biography at Answers.com]</ref><ref>[http://encyclopedia.farlex.com/Terry,+Dame+(Alice)+Ellen Hutchinson encyclopedia article on Terry family]</ref> Terry attended a boarding-school for girls at Sunnyside, [[Kingston upon Thames]], together with her favourite sister, Florence.<ref name=DNB/>
===Career=== Terry's first professional stage appearance was in July 1873 as Ophelia in a production of ''[[Hamlet]]'' directed by [[Tom Taylor]] in Manchester. Her first West End appearance came in October 1873 as Isabelle in a farce by [[John Maddison Morton]], ''A Game of Romps'' at the [[Olympic Theatre]], in the company of [[Henry Gartside Neville|Henry Neville]]. This was followed by the role of Lady Valeria in Morton's ''All that Glitters Is Not Gold'' at the same theatre. In 1874, she was Hero in [[Shakespeare]]'s ''[[Much Ado about Nothing]]'' at the Olympic. She then played a season at the [[Royal Strand Theatre|Strand Theatre]], and in 1875 appeared in ''Weak Woman'' by [[H. J. Byron]].
[[File:MarionTerry1882.JPG|left|thumb|Marion Terry, c. 1880]] Terry next joined the company at the [[Haymarket Theatre]] and became a protege of [[W. S. Gilbert]],<ref name=Stedman158>Stedman, p. 158</ref> soon appearing in several of his plays, including ''[[Dan'l Druce, Blacksmith]]'' (1876) as Dorothy,<ref>Ainger, p. 123</ref> ''[[The Palace of Truth]]'' (1876 revival),<ref>Ainger, p. 125</ref> ''[[Pygmalion and Galatea (play)|Pygmalion and Galatea]]'' (1877 revival) and ''[[Engaged (play)|Engaged]]'' (1877), creating the role of Belinda Treherne with great success.<ref name=DNB/> Also during that period, she first appeared in ''The Danischeffs'' by Lord Newry (1876), ''Fame'' by C. M. Rae (1877), ''Charles XII'' by [[James Planché]] (1877 revival),<ref>Adams, p. 274</ref> ''[[The Ne'er-do-Weel|The Vagabond]]'', by Gilbert (1878),<ref>Ainger, p. 150</ref> ''Two Orphans'' (1878),<ref>Ainger, p. 164</ref> ''The Crushed Tragedian'',<ref name=Stedman158/> and ''My Little Girl'' by [[Dion Boucicault]]. In 1879 she moved to the [[Prince of Wales's Theatre]] under the management of [[Squire Bancroft|the Bancrofts]] and then moved with the company to the Haymarket, performing in revivals of [[T. W. Robertson]]'s comedies, including as Blanche Haye in ''Ours'' and Bella in ''School''. In 1879 she also appeared as Mabel in ''Duty'' by James Albert and the title role in ''[[Gretchen (play)|Gretchen]]'' by Gilbert.<ref name=DNB/>
Now an established actress, Terry continued to play leading roles in contemporary plays. She was Bathsheba in the stage adaptation of ''[[Far from the Madding Crowd]]'' by [[Thomas Hardy]] and [[J. Comyns Carr]] (1882). The same year, she starred with [[Lottie Venne]] and [[Johnston Forbes-Robertson]] in G. W. Godfrey's comedy ''The Parvenu'' at the [[Royal Court Theatre|Court Theatre]].<ref>Culme, John. [http://footlightnotes.tripod.com/20050305home.html Footlight Notes No. 389] at Footlightnotes.tripod.com, accessed 18 November 2009</ref> She substituted for her sister Ellen, who was ill, as Viola in ''[[Twelfth Night]]'' at the [[Lyceum Theatre, London|Lyceum Theatre]] in 1884. In 1885 she played in ''The Magistrate'' by [[Arthur Wing Pinero]]. In 1887, she joined the company of [[Herbert Beerbohm Tree]] first at the [[Comedy Theatre]] and then at the Haymarket. That year, she also appeared in ''The Ballad-Monger'', by Walter Bessant. In February 1888, she starred in a revival of Gilbert's ''[[Broken Hearts]]''.<ref>[http://diamond.boisestate.edu/gas/other_gilbert/broken_hearts/intro.html Introduction to ''Broken Hearts''] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20080829120846/http://diamond.boisestate.edu/gas//other_gilbert/broken_hearts/intro.html |date=29 August 2008 }}, The Gilbert and Sullivan Archive</ref> Later that year, she toured the British provinces with [[Henry Irving]] in another of her sister Ellen's roles, Margaret in ''Faust''. She played Mrs. Erroll in ''The Real Little Lord Fauntleroy'' (1889),<ref>Foulkes, p. 98</ref> appeared in ''Cyrene'' by Alfred C. Calmour (1890), and appeared in 1891 in ''Sunlight and Shadow'' by R. C. Carton. She continued to tour with Irving's Lyceum company in the 1890s, as Rosamund in [[Alfred Lord Tennyson]]'s ''Becket'', as Portia in ''[[The Merchant of Venice]]'' (one of her sister's signature roles), and again as Margaret.<ref name=DNB/>
===Later years=== [[File:GilbertinRosencrantz.jpg|thumb|right|Terry and [[W. S. Gilbert]] in ''[[Rosencrantz and Guildenstern (Gilbert)|Rosencrantz and Guildenstern]]'']] In 1892 Terry played perhaps her most famous role, Mrs. Erlynne in ''[[Lady Windermere's Fan]]'', by [[Oscar Wilde]], at the [[St James's Theatre]]. This was followed by Hetty in ''The Cotton King'' by Sutton Vane Sr. (1893). In 1895, she appeared in ''Alabama'' by [[Augustus Thomas]], in the title role in ''Delia Harding'' by [[J. Comyns Carr]], and as Mrs. Peverel in ''[[Guy Domville]]'' by [[Henry James]]. In 1900 she played the roles of Rosalind and Portia at the Stratford festival. She was Nina in ''Forgiveness'' by J. Comyns Carr (1901), the title role in ''Eleanor'' by [[Mary Augusta Ward|Mrs. Humphrey Ward]] (1902), Susan Throssell in ''[[Quality Street (play)|Quality Street]]'' by [[J. M. Barrie]] (1902), and Audrie in ''Michael and His Lost Angel'' by [[Henry Arthur Jones]], among many other engagements.<ref name=DNB/>
In 1907, Terry performed in a [[Royal Command Performance]] of the 1855 [[Tom Taylor]] play, ''Still Waters Run Deep'', together with [[Charles Wyndham (actor)|Charles Wyndham]], before [[King Edward VII]].<ref name=stage>Gillan, Don. [http://www.stagebeauty.net/th-frames.html?http&&&www.stagebeauty.net/th-commnd.html A History of the Royal Command Performance], StageBeauty.net, accessed 16 June 2009</ref> She played Hamlet's mother in a 1908 revival of Gilbert's parody of ''Hamlet'', ''[[Rosencrantz and Guildenstern (Gilbert)|Rosencrantz and Guildenstern]]''. She toured in America and Canada in 1908 and 1909. Her last role was the Principessa della Cercola in ''Our Betters at the Globe'' by [[Somerset Maugham]] in 1923, fifty years after her first professional appearance. Suffering from arthritis and other ailments, she retired from the stage. In her last years, Terry lived in [[Paddington]], after having lived for many years at Buckingham Palace Mansions.<ref name=Timesobit>Obituary, ''The Times'', 22 August 1930</ref>
Terry died at her home in 1930, aged 76, of a cerebral haemorrhage and was buried at St Albans cemetery.<ref name=Timesobit/> She never married and, intensely private offstage, nothing is known of her romantic life. She left an estate of more than £12,000.<ref name=DNB/>

[[File:Mark Romanek Tokyo Intl Filmfest 2010.jpg|thumb|Romanek at the 2010 [[Tokyo International Film Festival]] ]]
American filmmaker [[Mark Romanek]] directed his first [[music video]] in 1986, for [[The The]]'s "Sweet Bird of Truth".<ref name="7videos"/> He earned his first [[MTV Video Music Award for Best Direction]] nomination for "[[Free Your Mind (song)|Free Your Mind]]", performed by [[En Vogue]], [[1993 MTV Video Music Awards|in 1993]].<ref name="1993VMA"/> Romanek later directed "[[Closer (Nine Inch Nails song)|Closer]]" for the [[industrial rock]] band [[Nine Inch Nails]], which contains imagery involving [[terror]], [[sexuality]], and [[animal cruelty]].<ref name="7videos"/><ref>{{cite web|url=http://entertainment.time.com/2011/07/28/the-30-all-time-best-music-videos/slide/nine-inch-nails-closer-1994/|title=The 30 All-Time Best Music Videos — Nine Inch Nails, ‘Closer’ (1994)|work=[[Time (magazine)|Time]]|author=ldetmer1271|date=July 26, 2011|accessdate=July 28, 2017|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20171007150743/http://entertainment.time.com/2011/07/28/the-30-all-time-best-music-videos/slide/nine-inch-nails-closer-1994/|archivedate=October 7, 2017|deadurl=no|df=}}</ref> In 1995, he directed the video for "[[Scream/Childhood|Scream]]", set in space and performed by [[Michael Jackson|Michael]] and [[Janet Jackson]], as well as the [[New Age]] surrealistic "[[Bedtime Story (Madonna song)|Bedtime Story]]", performed by [[Madonna (entertainer)|Madonna]].<ref>{{Cite journal |last=Boepple |first= Leanne |title = Scream: space odyssey Jackson-style.(video production; Michael and Janet Jackson video) | page = 52 |volume=29 | publisher = Theatre Crafts International | date = November 1, 1995 |issn=1063-9497 |postscript=<!--None-->}}</ref><ref>{{harvnb|Fouz-Hernández|Jarman-Ivens|2004|p=56}}</ref> They are two of the [[List of most expensive music videos|most expensive music videos ever made]], costing $7 million and $5 million, respectively.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.forbes.com/sites/hughmcintyre/2014/08/24/the-top-5-most-expensive-music-videos-of-all-time|title=The 5 Most Expensive Music Videos Of All Time|work=[[Forbes]]|first=Hugh|last= McIntyre |date=August 24, 2014|accessdate=July 28, 2017|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20170414083301/https://www.forbes.com/sites/hughmcintyre/2014/08/24/the-top-5-most-expensive-music-videos-of-all-time/#68b5c10673c5|archivedate=April 14, 2017|deadurl=no}}</ref> "Scream" gained 11 nominations at the [[1995 MTV Video Music Awards]], including Romanek's second Best Direction nomination,<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.mtv.com:80/ontv/vma/1995|title=MTV Video Music Awards 1995|publisher=[[MTV]]|accessdate=August 13, 2010|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20100813212229/http://www.mtv.com/ontv/vma/1995|archivedate=13 August 2010|deadurl=yes|df=}}</ref> and his first [[Grammy Award for Best Music Video, Short Form]].<ref name="Grammy"/>
In 1996, Romanek directed the ''[[Mary Poppins]]''-inspired "[[Novocaine for the Soul]]" for the [[Rock music|rock]] band [[Eels (band)|Eels]].<ref name="houston"/> The following year, he directed [[Fiona Apple]]'s "[[Criminal (Fiona Apple song)|Criminal]]", which explores themes of [[voyeurism]] and [[adolescence]];<ref>{{cite news|last=Zeltner|first=Mark|url=http://www.imagesjournal.com/issue05/features/fiona.htm |title=Fiona Apple's 'Criminal' and Video Voyeurism for the '90s|work=[[Image (journal)|Image]]|issue=5|accessdate=June 28, 2007|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20180207030755/http://www.imagesjournal.com/issue05/features/fiona.htm|archivedate=February 7, 2018|deadurl=no}}</ref> and won his second Grammy Award for Best Music Video, Short Form for "[[Got 'til It's Gone]]", performed by Janet Jackson, [[Q-Tip (musician)|Q-Tip]] and [[Joni Mitchell]].<ref name="Grammy">{{cite web| title = Artist: Mark Romanek| publisher=[[The Recording Academy]] | url=https://www.grammy.com/grammys/artists/mark-romanek| accessdate = March 18, 2015|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20180430051351/https://www.grammy.com/grammys/artists/mark-romanek|archivedate=April 30, 2018|deadurl=no}}</ref> For his work in "[[Hurt (Johnny Cash cover song)|Hurt]]" (2003), performed by [[Johnny Cash]], Romanek earned another MTV nomination, and won his third Grammy.<ref name="Grammy"/><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.mtv.com/ontv/vma/2003/|title=MTV Video Music Awards 2003|publisher=MTV|accessdate=August 15, 2010|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20100725031620/http://www.mtv.com/ontv/vma/2003/|archivedate=25 July 2010|deadurl=yes|df=}}</ref> In 2004, he directed the [[Autobiography|auto-biographical]] music video for [[Jay-Z]]'s "[[99 Problems]]", for which he won his first MTV award.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.mtv.com/ontv/vma/2004/|title=MTV Video Music Awards 2004|publisher=MTV|accessdate=August 15, 2010|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20100725031625/http://www.mtv.com/ontv/vma/2004/|archivedate=25 July 2010|deadurl=yes|df=}}</ref> Their subsequent collaborations—the [[Installation art|installation-style]] 10-minute [[short film]] for "[[Picasso Baby]]" (2013),{{efn|name=picasso}} and the [[animation]] video for "[[The Story of O.J.]]" (2017)<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.rollingstone.com/music/news/jay-z-releases-animated-the-story-of-oj-video-from-444-w490544|title=Jay-Z Releases Animated 'The Story of O.J.' Video From '4:44'|date=June 30, 2017|accessdate=June 30, 2017|work=Rolling Stone|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20171216034656/https://www.rollingstone.com/music/news/jay-z-releases-animated-the-story-of-oj-video-from-444-w490544|archivedate=December 16, 2017|deadurl=no}}</ref>—were nominated for Grammy Award for Best Music Video.<ref name="Grammy"/>
Romanek made his feature-film directorial debut with the 1986 comedy-drama feature ''[[Static (1986 film)|Static]]'', which was nominated for Grand Jury Prize at the 1986 [[Sundance Film Festival]].<ref name="rausch">{{harvnb|Rausch|2008|page=192}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://history.sundance.org/films/1126/static|title=Static: Archives: Sundance Institute|publisher=[[Sundance Film Festival]]|accessdate=August 15, 2010|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20170926191003/http://history.sundance.org/films/1126/static|archivedate=September 26, 2017|deadurl=no}}</ref> He received a [[Saturn Award for Best Writing]] nomination for his work in the psychological thriller ''[[One Hour Photo]]'' (2002), which starred [[Robin Williams]].<ref>{{cite web|url=https://variety.com/2003/film/awards/towers-report-top-saturn-nominees-1117881826/|title='Towers,' 'Report' top Saturn nominees|work=[[Variety (magazine)|Variety]] |accessdate=1 November 2010|date=March 6, 2003|first=Jevon|last=Phillips|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20170926200830/http://variety.com/2003/film/awards/towers-report-top-saturn-nominees-1117881826/|archivedate=September 26, 2017|deadurl=no}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.saturnawards.org/saturn_rings/saturn_rings_04.pdf |title=A Look at the 29th Annual Saturn Awards |accessdate=May 4, 2012 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120402174643/http://www.saturnawards.org/saturn_rings/saturn_rings_04.pdf |archivedate=April 2, 2012|publisher=[[Academy of Science Fiction, Fantasy and Horror Films]]}}</ref> In 2010, he directed the romantic drama film ''[[Never Let Me Go (2010 film)|Never Let Me Go]]'', starring [[Carey Mulligan]], [[Keira Knightley]] and [[Andrew Garfield]], for which he was nominated for [[British Independent Film Award]] for Best Director.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://bifa.org.uk/news/mo%C3%ABt-british-independent-film-awards-announce-nominations-and-jury-13th-edition|title=The Moët British Independent Film Awards Announce Nominations and Jury for 13th Edition |publisher=[[British Independent Film Awards]] |accessdate=1 November 2010|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20101104213137/http://bifa.org.uk/news/mo%C3%ABt-british-independent-film-awards-announce-nominations-and-jury-13th-edition <!--Added by H3llBot-->|archivedate=4 November 2010}}</ref> Romanek also directed several [[Television advertisement|commercials]] for [[iPod]], [[Nike, Inc.|Nike]], and [[ESPN]].

'''Marnitz Louis Boshoff''' (born 11 January 1989) is a South African [[rugby union]] player who usually plays as a [[Fly-half (rugby union)|fly-half]] or [[Fullback (rugby union)|fullback]]. He plays for the {{Rut Bulls}} in [[Super Rugby]], the {{Rut Blue Bulls}} in the [[Currie Cup]] and the {{Rut Blue Bulls XV}} in the [[Rugby Challenge (South Africa)|Rugby Challenge]], having previously played for South African provincial sides {{Rut Griquas}}, the {{Rut Blue Bulls}} and the {{Rut Golden Lions}} in the [[Currie Cup]] and for [[Super Rugby]] side the {{Rut Lions}}. He also had a short stint with Irish provincial side [[Connacht Rugby|Connacht]] in the [[Pro14]].<ref name="Boshoff granted early release by Connacht">{{cite press release | url=http://www.planetrugby.com/news/connacht-grants-boshoff-an-early-release/ | title=Boshoff granted early release by Connacht | publisher=Planet Rugby | date=2 August 2016 | accessdate=2 August 2016}}</ref>
He played in a single test match for {{nrut|South Africa}} in 2014 and also featured for invitational side the [[Barbarians F.C.|Barbarians]].
==Rugby career==
===Youth rugby===
Born in [[Nelspruit]] in the [[Mpumalanga]] province of [[South Africa]], Boshoff is a graduate of Nelspruit Hoërskool and attended the [[University of Pretoria]]. He was part of the youth team of Nelspruit-based side the [[Pumas (rugby team)|Pumas]] from 2005 to 2007, before joining the academy of the [[Pretoria]]-based [[Blue Bulls]].
===Blue Bulls===
Boshoff first played at provincial level for the [[Blue Bulls]], playing for them from 2009 to 2011 after coming through their youth side. During his time with the Blue Bulls, he played 24 times, scoring 130 points.
===Griquas===
In 2012, Boshoff moved to the [[Griquas (rugby)|Griquas]]. He spent one year there, making 13 appearances and scoring 37 points.
===Golden Lions / Lions===
He joined the {{Rut Golden Lions}} for 2013.<ref name="Lions announce more signings">{{cite web | url=http://www.supersport.com/rugby/sa-rugby/news/121010/Lions_announce_more_signings | title=Lions announce more signings | publisher=Supersport | date=10 Oct 2012 | accessdate=10 Oct 2012}}</ref>
He played in both legs of the {{Rut Lions}}' [[2013 Super Rugby season#Promotion/Relegation Play-Offs|promotion/relegation matches]] after the [[2013 Super Rugby season]],<ref name="Southern Kings 19-26 MTN Lions">{{SA Rugby Match Centre | id=112664 | homeid=15674 | awayid=15664 | leagueid=1514 | hometeam=Southern Kings | homescore=19 | awayscore=26 | awayteam=MTN Lions | matchdate=26 July 2013 | date=27 July 2016}}</ref><ref name="MTN Lions 18-23 Southern Kings">{{SA Rugby Match Centre | id=112674 | homeid=15664 | awayid=15674 | leagueid=1514 | hometeam=MTN Lions | homescore=18 | awayscore=23 | awayteam=Southern Kings | matchdate=3 August 2013 | date=27 July 2016}}</ref> which saw the {{Rut Lions}} regain their spot in Super Rugby.
After a season that saw him finish as the top points scorer for the {{Rut Golden Lions}} in the [[2013 Currie Cup Premier Division]], he was then included in the {{Rut Lions}} squad for the [[2014 Super Rugby season]]<ref name="2014 Lions Super Rugby squad">{{cite press release|url=http://www.lionsrugby.co.za/lionsnews.aspx?item=4128&multiid=1010&archive=0 |title=2014 Lions Super Rugby squad |publisher=Lions |date=11 February 2014 |accessdate=11 February 2014 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140222152732/http://www.lionsrugby.co.za/lionsnews.aspx?item=4128&multiid=1010&archive=0 |archivedate=22 February 2014 |df= }}</ref> and made his [[Super Rugby]] debut in a man-of-the-match performance in the opening match of the season, scoring all the Lions' points – including a last-minute drop goal – to help them beat the {{Rut Cheetahs}} 21–20 in [[Bloemfontein]].<ref name="Match Centre: Cheetahs v Lions">{{cite web | url=http://www.sanzarrugby.com/superrugby/match-centre/?season=2014&competition=205&match=514011 | title=Match Centre: Cheetahs v Lions | publisher=SANZAR | date=15 February 2014 | accessdate=15 February 2014}}</ref><ref name="Toyota Cheetahs 20-21 Lions">{{SA Rugby Match Centre | id=113674 | homeid=16144 | awayid=16154 | leagueid=1574 | hometeam=Toyota Cheetahs | homescore=20 | awayscore=21 | awayteam=Lions | matchdate=15 February 2014 | date=27 July 2016}}</ref>
He was the Golden Lions' first-choice fly-half during the [[2014 Currie Cup Premier Division|2014]] and [[2015 Currie Cup Premier Division|2015]] [[Currie Cup]] competitions, with the Lions reaching the final both times and winning the trophy in 2015, with Boshoff again finishing as the top points scorer.
===Connacht===
In March 2016, Irish [[Pro14|Pro12]] side [[Connacht Rugby|Connacht]] announced that they secured Boshoff's services on a two-year contract.<ref name="Connacht sign Springbok outhalf Marnitz Boshoff">{{cite press release | url=http://www.connachtrugby.ie/connacht-sign-springbok-international-outhalf-marnitz-boshoff | title=Connacht sign Springbok outhalf Marnitz Boshoff | publisher=Connacht Rugby | date=14 March 2016 | accessdate=14 March 2016 | archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160314155858/http://www.connachtrugby.ie/connacht-sign-springbok-international-outhalf-marnitz-boshoff | archivedate=14 March 2016}}</ref>
===Representative rugby===
In May 2014, Boshoff was one of eight uncapped players that were called up to a [[South Africa national rugby union team|Springbok]] training camp prior to the [[2014 mid-year rugby union tests]].<ref name="Springbok training squad for Durban camp named">{{SA Rugby Article | id=2449174 | leagueid=1674 | title=Springbok training squad for Durban camp named | date=19 May 2014 | accessdate=6 June 2016 | archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160607175936/http://www.sarugby.co.za/article.aspx?id=2449174&leagueid=1674 | archivedate=6 June 2016}}</ref> Although not initially selected in the 36-man squad,<ref name="Seven uncapped players in Springbok squad">{{cite web | url=http://www.sarugby.net/component/supersportcontent/20658?view=news | title=Seven uncapped players in Springbok squad | publisher=South African Rugby Union | date=31 May 2014 | accessdate=31 May 2014}}</ref> Boshoff was called up to the squad when [[Damian de Allende]] suffered a knee ligament injury.<ref name="Springboks suffer De Allende injury setback">{{cite web | url=http://www.sarugby.net/component/supersportcontent/20663?view=news | title=Springboks suffer De Allende injury setback | publisher=South African Rugby Union | date=2 June 2014 | accessdate=2 June 2014}}</ref> He played off the bench against [[Scotland national rugby union team|Scotland]] and scored his first points by converting a try.
He was chosen to represent the [[Barbarian F.C.|Barbarians]] to face [[Australia national rugby union team|Australia]] on 1 November 2014 at [[Twickenham Stadium|Twickenham]]. He came off the bench and scored two conversions and a try, but the Barbarians lost 36–40.

{{other people}} {{Use dmy dates|date=July 2015}} {{Infobox person | name = Michael A. Spencer | image = | image_upright = | alt = | caption = | birth_date = {{birth date and age|1955|05|30|df=yes}} | birth_place = [[Kuala Lumpur]], [[British Malaya]] (now Malaysia) | death_date = | death_place = | residence = London | nationality = British | other_names = Spence, Spens{{cite web|title=Michael Spencer: The City's top Tory on why Theresa May is not doing enough to defend business on Brexit|url=https://www.standard.co.uk/business/michael-spencer-the-city-s-top-tory-on-why-theresa-may-is-not-doing-enough-to-defend-business-on-a3486466.html}} | citizenship = | education = | alma_mater = | occupation = Financial broker; investor | years_active = 40+ | era = | organization = | known_for = ICAP, ICAP Charity Day, political fundraising | notable_works = | style = | home_town = London | salary = | net_worth = £800m{{cite web | title=Profiles: 100-196= | website=The Sunday Times | date=2017-05-07 | url=https://www.thetimes.co.uk/article/rich-list-2017-profiles-100-196-cxdh2mzls | access-date=2018-03-15}} | party = Conservative Party | boards = ''inter alia'' Alresford Racing Ltd, Nex Group PLC, The Conservative Party Foundation Limited, Ipgl (Holdings) Limited,Sirai House Limited, Bi Wines and Spirits Limited, Sirai Llp, Finsbury Fine Art Llp, ICAP PLC, InterCapital Brokerage Services Limited | spouse = Lorraine Spencer (div. 2008)
Sarah, Marchioness of Milford Haven (m. 2016) | children = 1 daughter, 2 sons | parents = | relatives = | awards = | website = }} '''Michael Alan Spencer''' (born 30 May 1955) is a British businessman and philanthropist. He is the founder and chief executive of [[NEX Group|NEX Group plc]], a UK-based business focused on electronic markets and post trade business. NEX Group was formerly known as ICAP plc, until the sale of its voice-broking business to [[Tullett Prebon]] in December 2016. Spencer has been described as the richest self-made person in the City of London and as a "...City grandee".{{cite web | title=City grandee Michael Spencer could be in line for £450m payday as Nex approached over takeover | website=The Telegraph | date=2018-03-15 | url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/business/2018/03/15/city-grandee-michael-spencer-could-line-450m-payday-nex-approached/ | access-date=2018-03-19}}{{cite web | last=Blackhurst | first=Chris | title=City Interview: ICAP's Michael Spencer | website=This is Money | date=2008-10-09 | url=http://www.thisismoney.co.uk/money/news/article-1644479/City-Interview-ICAPs-Michael-Spencer.html | access-date=2018-03-19}} ==Education== Spencer was born in British Malaya. His father was an economist and international civil servant, his mother a linguist. Spencer's early childhood saw him move from his birth country to Sudan and then Ethiopia. At age eight he was sent to England to board, latterly at [[Worth School|Worth Abbey Benedictine (OSB) School, Sussex]]. He read physics at [[Corpus Christi College, Oxford]], after which he considered becoming an [[Astrophysics|astrophysicist]].{{cite web|url=https://www.theguardian.com/business/2006/may/14/theobserver.observerbusiness3 |title=Big beast of the City hooked on the buzz of the markets |publisher=theguardian.com |first1=Richard |last1= Wachman |date=May 13, 2006 }} Spencer is an Honorary Fellow of Corpus Christi and an Honorary Doctor of Loughborough University.{{cite web | title=Emeritus, Honorary, Claymond and Foundation Fellows | website=Corpus Christi College Oxford | url=https://www.ccc.ox.ac.uk/Emeritus-Honorary-Claymond-and-Foundation-Fellows/ | access-date=2018-03-19}}{{cite web | title=Winter Ceremonies celebrate honorary graduates | website=Loughborough University - A top ten university and 1st in the UK for Student Experience | date=2012-12-14 | url=http://www.lboro.ac.uk/service/publicity/news-releases/2012/227_Winter_hon_grads.html | access-date=2018-03-19}} ==Early career== While still a student Spencer made £30,000 dealing in shares.{{Cite news|url=https://www.thisismoney.co.uk/money/markets/article-5506931/Americans-swoop-2-5bn-City-financial-technology-titan-Nex-Group.html|title=Americans swoop for £2.5bn City financial technology titan Nex Group|work=This is Money|access-date=2018-09-20}} In 1976 he joined city broker Simon and Coates. There he took a large [[Short (finance)|short position]] on the price of gold prior to the [[Soviet–Afghan War|Russian invasion of Afghanistan]]; the price of gold quadrupled in response to the invasion and Spencer's position incurred heavy losses, leading to his dismissal.{{Cite news|url=http://www.thisismoney.co.uk/money/news/article-1529551/The-rare-beast-who-became-the-worlds-top-money-broker.html|title=The rare beast who became the world's top money broker|work=This is Money|access-date=2018-03-14}} In 1981 he joined [[Drexel Burnham]], rising to Vice President before being fired for trading errors. From 1983 to 1986 he was a Director at futures firm Charles Fulton; when that firm floated, Spencer used £50,000 from his proceeds to co-found his first business, along with three colleagues.{{Cite news|url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/business/2018/06/02/icap-boss-michael-spencermisdemeanours-city-confined-small-minority/|title=Icap founder Michael Spencer on Corbyn the economic juvenile and not wanting to end his career on a losing battle|last=Marlow|first=Ben|date=2018-06-02|work=The Telegraph|access-date=2018-06-04|language=en-GB|issn=0307-1235}} ==ICAP== Spencer co-founded Intercapital Brokers in 1986.{{cite web|url=https://www.theguardian.com/business/2006/may/14/theobserver.observerbusiness3|title=Big beast of the City hooked on the buzz of the markets|last1=Wachman|first1=Richard|date=May 13, 2006|publisher=theguardian.com}} Over its 20 years as a listed company, its total shareholder return was close to 6,000 per cent.{{Cite web|url=https://www.ft.com/content/9b846900-dd0e-11e8-9f04-38d397e6661c?kbc=undefined|title=City maverick Michael Spencer: Trading? ‘It’s a contact sport’|last=Jenkins|first=Patrick|date=|website=FT.com|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=}} Intercapital was the first to launch a real-time screen that displayed live prices. In 1998, it was acquired by [[Exco International|Exco plc]] in a [[reverse takeover]], and the enlarged business was renamed Intercapital plc.{{cite web|url=http://www.numiscorp.com/uploads/field2_29-04-2003_14_32_43_3534_Board%20Changes,%20Equity%20Issue,%20LTIP.pdf|title=Numis Corporation Board Changes|author=|date=|website=numiscorp.com|accessdate=29 March 2018}} In 1999, the company merged with Garban plc to create Garban-Intercapital plc, the largest inter-dealer broker in the world with more than 5,000 employees across 63 offices.{{cite web|url=http://www.icap.com/about-the-group/history.aspx|title=Who we are|author=|date=|website=www.icap.com|accessdate=29 March 2018}} Garban renamed itself ICAP plc in 2001 (its full name did not fit on trading screens, hence the abbreviation to ICAP) . Functioning as an inter-dealer broker, ICAP brought together large financial institutions in search of buyers and sellers for corporate and government bonds, foreign currency, commodities and other financial products. The firm collected commissions and connected clients via its electronic trading platforms. In 2006 Icap entered the [[FTSE 100]], one of a small number of companies to do so with a founder CEO. Following the sale of its voice broking business to banking firm [[TP ICAP|Tullett Prebon]] in December 2016, ICAP plc was renamed NEX Group, while Tullett Prebon became TP ICAP. Spencer sold the majority of his stake in TP ICAP in January 2017. He remains CEO and largest shareholder of Nex Group, as of February 2017.{{cite web|url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/business/2017/01/10/michael-spencer-sells-tp-icap-shares/|title=Michael Spencer sells most of his TP Icap shares|last1=Dakers|first1=Marion|date=January 10, 2017|publisher=telegraph.co.uk}} In February 2010, Spencer made £45m from the sale of ICAP shares weeks before the company issued a [[profit warning]] that resulted in a 16% fall in the firm's share price.{{cite web|url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/news/politics/conservative/7164041/Tory-treasurer-Michael-Spencer-attacked-over-45m-share-sale.html|title=Tory treasurer Michael Spencer attacked over £45m share sale|quote="If someone's attempting to try to start a political debate, it's not supportable by the real facts. There's a proper procedure to follow here. The proper procedure was followed. It's ridiculous for someone to suggest that I have behaved improperly. I haven't."|date=5 February 2010|publisher=[[Daily Telegraph]]}} In September 2013 ICAP was implicated in the global [[Libor scandal|Libor interest rate scandal]] and fined $87m (£54m) by the US [[Commodity Futures Trading Commission]] and Britain's [[Financial Conduct Authority]].{{cite web|url=https://www.reuters.com/article/us-libor-trial-broker-idUSKCN0V616A|title=Ex-brokers celebrate as sixth Libor defendant walks free|date=January 28, 2016|website=reuters.com|accessdate=February 13, 2017}}{{cite web|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/business-24250750|title=Libor: ICAP fined $87m and three traders charged with fraud|publisher=[[BBC News]]}} In March 2014 British prosecutors filed charges against three former ICAP employees for their role in the affair. They were among a global group of finance professionals to be investigated, including staff from [[Barclays]], [[UBS]], [[Citigroup]] and RP Martin. In January 2016 the three ICAP employees were unanimously acquitted in the UK; the US Department of Justice dropped charges against them in July 2016.{{cite web | last=Turvill | first=William | title=Three former ICAP brokers have US Libor charges dropped | website=City A.M. | date=2016-07-07 | url=http://www.cityam.com/245006/three-former-icap-brokers-have-us-libor-charges-dropped | access-date=2018-03-19}}{{cite web | title=Libor brokers 'were scapegoats' | website=BBC News | date=2016-01-28 | url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/business-35428279 | access-date=2018-03-19}} Spencer was not implicated but issued a public apology on behalf of ICAP.{{cite web|last1=Armitage|first1=Jim|title=Michael Spencer: The City's top Tory on why Theresa May is not doing enough to defend business on Brexit|url=https://www.standard.co.uk/business/michael-spencer-the-city-s-top-tory-on-why-theresa-may-is-not-doing-enough-to-defend-business-on-a3486466.html|website=Standard.co.uk|accessdate=15 March 2018|date=10 March 2017|quote=He clearly feels angry at his traders and hard done by at Icap's punishment. "It is undoubtedly the low point of my career and the history of Icap. But I believe the firm's reputation for honesty and ethics with our clients has stood the test of time. It was a pity the conduct of three individuals caused not only financial damage but reputational damage well beyond the proportionality of their misconduct."}} In March 2018 NEX announced an approach by CME Group further to a proposed acquisition. CME offered £3.8bn in a cash-and-share deal, valuing Spencer's stake at approximately £668m.{{Cite web|url=https://www.euromoney.com/article/b17m2dlgg67dq6/macaskill-on-markets-nex39s-michael-spencer-a-title-for-the-billion-dollar-broker?copyrightInfo=true|title=Macaskill on markets: NEX's Michael Spencer – a title for the billion dollar broker?|website=Euromoney|language=en|access-date=2018-04-16}}{{Cite news|url=https://www.fnlondon.com/articles/cme-plans-hundreds-of-job-cuts-after-3-8bn-nex-takeover-20180329|title=CME plans hundreds of job cuts after £3.8bn NEX takeover|last=Agini|first=Samuel|access-date=2018-04-16|language=en-GB}} By the time the deal completed in November 2018 Spencer's stake had grown to over £700m, half of which he received in cash, raising his net worth to over £1bn. As a listed company, Nex's total shareholder return was close to 6,000 per cent. == Other business interests == In 1997 Spencer purchased a controlling interest in spread betting firm [[City Index Group]], acquiring his stake from the firm's founders. City Index was later sold for $118m to financial services company [[GAIN Capital]], netting Spencer more than $80m.{{cite web|url=https://www.ft.com/content/09b7e6ba-60fc-11e4-b935-00144feabdc0|title=Spencer sells City Index to GAIN Capital|last1=Agnew|first1=Harriet|date=October 31, 2014|publisher=ft.com}} Spencer has held stakes in numerous public and private companies. He is a director and majority shareholder in IPGL Limited, a private holding company making investments on behalf of Spencer and other family trusts. He is also an early-stage investor in Temple Grange Partners, a consultancy that finds compliance specialists for financial markets, and an investor in mobile gaming software company Probability.{{Cite web|url=https://www.ft.com/content/b4566d04-c4a3-11e7-a1d2-6786f39ef675|title=Subscribe to read|website=Financial Times|language=en-GB|access-date=2018-03-14}} He is a co-owner of Exotix, a frontier markets investment banking boutique.{{Cite news|url=http://www.investmenteurope.net/other/exotix-enters-strategic-partnership-with-tlg-capital/|title=Exotix enters strategic partnership with TLG Capital - Investment Europe|date=2013-01-31|work=Investment Europe|access-date=2018-05-17|language=en-US}} He also owns a stake in Cluff Natural Resources, a energy resources investor. In 2018 he led an investment round in two cyber security firms: Veridium, a [[Biometrics|biometric]] authentication startup, and Glasswall Solutions, a file regeneration technology firm.{{Cite news|url=http://www.cityam.com/288427/city-veteran-michael-spencer-invests-millions-into|title=City veteran Michael Spencer invests millions into fintech startup|last=Nicolle|first=Emily|date=2018-06-29|access-date=2018-07-09|language=en}}.{{Cite news|url=https://www.standard.co.uk/business/smallcap-spotlight-michael-spencer-ups-his-stake-in-cluff-natural-resources-porta-communications-has-a3825501.html|title=Small-cap spotlight: Michael Spencer ups his stake in Cluff Resources|work=Evening Standard|access-date=2018-05-17|language=en-GB}}{{Cite news|url=https://www.finextra.com/pressarticle/75410/michael-spencer-invests-in-15-million-funding-round-for-cybersecurity-outfit-glasswall|title=Michael Spencer invests in £15 million funding round for cybersecurity outfit Glasswall|last=Finextra|date=2018-09-13|work=Finextra Research|access-date=2018-10-04|language=en}} Spencer is also an investor in Elvie, a female health tech startup{{Cite news|url=https://techcrunch.com/2017/03/22/elvie-pulls-in-6m-series-a-to-build-a-global-female-health-tech-brand/?guccounter=1|title=Elvie pulls in $6M Series A to build a global female health tech brand|work=TechCrunch|access-date=2018-08-16|language=en-US}} In 2018 he became Chairman and majority shareholder of investment firm FCFM.{{Cite news|url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/business/2018/08/05/michael-spencer-takes-lead-role-fcfm/|title=Michael Spencer takes lead role at FCFM|last=Burton|first=Lucy|date=2018-08-05|work=The Telegraph|access-date=2018-08-16|language=en-GB|issn=0307-1235}} He is an investor in Viewforth Investment Partners, a London-based hedge fund focusing on mid-cap European securities.{{Cite web|url=https://www.ft.com/content/a8259be6-9cd8-11e8-9702-5946bae86e6d|title=Subscribe to read|website=Financial Times|language=en-GB|access-date=2018-08-16}} Spencer is a former chairman of stockbroker Numis Securities. He believes in a long-term role for [[Cryptocurrency|cryptocurrencies]]. He opposes [[Markets in Financial Instruments Directive 2004|MiFID II]].{{Cite news|url=https://www.risk.net/node/5352251|title=Nex's Spencer on tech, Brexit and the UK's identity crisis - Risk.net|date=2017-11-13|work=Risk.net|access-date=2018-03-15|language=en}} In 2011 Spencer was made Chairman of Bordeaux Index, the online wine trading exchange in which he is an investor.{{cite web|url=http://www.decanter.com/wine-news/icap-chief-joins-bordeaux-index-48459/|title=ICAP chief joins Bordeaux Index|last1=Kevany|first1=Sophie|date=December 7, 2011|publisher=decanter.com}} He also holds a stake in English wine maker Chapel Down.{{Citation|title=Wray, Nigel William, (born 9 April 1948), non-executive Director: Prestbury Investment Holdings, since 2003; Chapel Down Group plc (formerly English Wines Group plc), since 2004|date=2007-12-01|url=https://dx.doi.org/10.1093/ww/9780199540884.013.40759|work=Who's Who|publisher=Oxford University Press}} He is the owner of Sirai House, a commercial lodge in Kenya.{{Cite web|url=https://www.businessdailyafrica.com/lifestyle/profiles/Laidback-billionaire/4258438-4543636-12na3gb/index.html|title=Laidback billionaire|last=Biko|first=Jackson|date=4 May 2018|website=BusinesDailyAfrica.com|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=}} ==Politics== Spencer served as Treasurer of the [[Conservative Party (UK)|Conservative Party]] from 2006 to 2010, during which time the party's finances moved from a deficit of £8m into a surplus of £75m.{{Cite news|url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/news/2016/08/01/who-is-michael-spencer/|title=Who is Michael Spencer?|last=Hope|first=Christopher|date=2016-08-01|work=The Telegraph|access-date=2018-03-14|last2=Hughes|first2=Laura|language=en-GB|issn=0307-1235}}{{cite web|url=http://www.conservatives.com/people/members_of_the_board/spencer_michael.aspx|title=The Conservative Party - People - Members of the Board - Michael Spencer|date=20 May 2010|publisher=[[Conservative Party (UK)|Conservative Party]]|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20100520014546/http://www.conservatives.com/people/members_of_the_board/spencer_michael.aspx|archivedate=20 May 2010|deadurl=bot: unknown|df=}} He is the Chairman of the Conservative Party Foundation, a charity established to strengthen the financial future of the Conservative Party.{{cite web|url=http://www.theconservativefoundation.co.uk/index.php?page=who&win=board&item=Michael_Spencer|title=Spencer sells City Index to GAIN Capital|date=February 9, 2017|publisher=theconservativefoundation.co.uk}} Spencer is a noted donor to the Conservative Party, taking dinner with then-Prime Minister [[David Cameron]].{{cite web|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/uk-politics-17508271|title=David Cameron publishes list of all donors dining at No 10|date=26 March 2012|publisher=BBC News}} ICAP and Spencer have made £4.6m in donations to the party, although Spencer has been critical of the [[Second May ministry|May government']]s business policies; he has not donated to the party since the [[United Kingdom general election, 2017|2017 UK general election]].{{cite web|url=http://www.huffingtonpost.co.uk/2013/09/26/cameron-icap-libor_n_3993687.html|title=Cameron Urged To Give Back The £4.6m From Libor Donor|last1=Bennett|first1=Asa|date=26 September 2013|publisher=[[Huffington Post]]}} Spencer was nominated for a peerage in Cameron's [[2016 Prime Minister's Resignation Honours|resignation honours]] list, for charity fundraising and service to the Conservative party while Treasurer, but reportedly his nomination was blocked by the [[Cabinet Office]].{{cite web|url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/news/2016/07/22/david-camerons-recommendation-of-a-peerage-for-michael-spencer-h/|title=David Cameron's recommendation of a peerage for Michael Spencer 'holding up resignation honours list'|last1=Hope|first1=Christopher|date=22 July 2016|publisher=telegraph.co.uk}} Spencer has been reported to favour [[positive discrimination]] employment policies for women but is against gender-based employment quotas, believing them to wrongly presuppose prejudice among all male employers. He has criticised the UK Government's pay gap review as a distraction from Brexit.{{Cite news|url=https://www.bloomberg.com/news/articles/2018-05-15/brexit-britain-wasting-time-on-pay-gap-billionaire-spencer-says|title=Brexit Britain Wasting Time on Pay Gap, Billionaire Spencer Says|date=2018-05-15|work=Bloomberg.com|access-date=2018-05-17|language=en}} Spencer was among the first to employ female brokers in the City. He voted for the UK to remain in the EU. He later said that he had long been undecided on the issue, and that his Remain vote was cast without "...great angelical zeal." He has spoken of becoming a cheerleader for enterprise after the sale of NEX. == Awards and recognition == * Named to ''Risk'' magazine's Hall of Fame (2003) * ''Entrepreneur of the Year'' at [[CNBC]]'s European Business Leader Awards (2007){{cite web|url=https://www.cnbc.com/id/18420476|title=CNBC Europe Names the Top European Business Leaders For 2007|date=May 1, 2007|publisher=theguardian.com}} * ''Judges Special Award'', [[Beacon Fellowship]] Prize (2007){{cite web|url=http://beaconawards.org.uk/beacon-fellows|title=Beacon Fellows|date=February 9, 2017|publisher=beaconawards.org}} * Ernst & Young World [[Ernst & Young Entrepreneur of the Year Awards|''Entrepreneur Of The Year'']]. Spencer was picked from over 50 country finalists, each one an Ernst & Young Entrepreneur Of The Year in their home country (2010){{cite web|url=http://www.ey.com/uk/en/newsroom/news-releases/eoy---10-06-06---michael-spencer-named-weoy-2010|title=ICAP’s Michael Spencer named EY World Entrepreneur Of The Year 2010|date=June 6, 2010|publisher=ey.com}}{{cite web|url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/finance/newsbysector/banksandfinance/7807197/entrepreneur-mahindra-geely-icap.html|title=ICAP founder Michael Spencer wins Ernst & Young's Global Entrepreneur of the Year award|date=June 6, 2010|publisher=telegraph.co.uk}} * Queen's Award for International Trade (2005 and 2011){{cite web | title=Subscribe to read | website=Financial Times | date=2017-09-07 | url=https://www.ft.com/content/f9f771b0-6bf3-11e0-b36e-00144feab49a | access-date=2018-03-19}} * Institutional Investor's ''World's Top 50 Financial Technologists'' (#13) (2016){{cite web|url=http://www.institutionalinvestor.com/Article/3570483/The-2016-Tech-50-Michael-Spencer.html#/.WJzAEn_kqTd|title=Institutional Investor Top 50 2016|date=July 18, 2016|publisher=institutionalinvestor.com}} * ''Lifetime Achievement Award'', Futures & Options World (2016){{cite web|url=http://www.fow.com/3593051/Icap-CEO-to-get-Lifetime-Achievement-Award.html|title=ICAP CEO to get Lifetime Achievement Award|date=October 13, 2016|publisher=fow.com}} == Philanthropy == In 1993, Spencer founded the ICAP Charity Day, an annual event in which royalty and celebrities man the trading desks at ICAP and the broking firm donates the day's revenue to charities.{{cite web|url=https://www.standard.co.uk/business/michael-spencer-icap-founder-tory-grandee-and-party-animal-looks-forward-to-life-after-tullett-a3129936.html|title=Michael Spencer: Icap founder, Tory grandee and party animal looks forward to life after Tullett Prebon merger|date=December 4, 2015|publisher=ey.com}} As of February 2017, the event has raised over £140 million and backed 2,200 charitable projects. He has said that the Charity Day is his proudest achievement in business, alongside breaking into the FTSE100 with ICAP.{{cite web|url=http://www.icapcharityday.com/an-overview/history|title=An overview|date=February 9, 2017|publisher=icapcharityday.com}}{{Cite news|url=http://www.cityam.com/286409/editors-notes-anti-brexit-party-cant-quite-get-its-act|title=Editor's Notes: Anti-Brexit party can’t quite get its act together|last=May|first=Christian|date=2018-05-25|access-date=2018-06-04|language=en}} Royalty and celebrities who have manned ICAP phones include: [[Prince William, Duke of Cambridge|Prince William]] and [[Catherine, Duchess of Cambridge]], [[Prince Harry]], [[Camilla, Duchess of Cornwall]], [[Mo Farah|Sir Mo Farrah]], [[Sir Stirling Moss]], [[Gillian Anderson]], [[Halle Berry]], [[George W. Bush]], [[Samantha Cameron]], [[Cheryl (singer)|Cheryl Cole]], [[Kelsey Grammer|Kelsey Grammar,]] [[Tom Hardy]], [[Goldie Hawn]], [[Chris Hemsworth]], [[Chris Hoy|Sir Chris Hoy]], [[Bill Nighy]], [[Julie Walters]], [[Oprah Winfrey]] and [[Reese Witherspoon]]. Spencer is a founder and trustee of the Borana Conservation Trust, a charity which supports critically endangered species in Kenya's Borana and Laikipia regions.{{cite web|url=https://www.fnlondon.com/articles/fn-tandt-awards-winners-2016-decade-of-excellence-award-michael-spencer-group-ceo-icap-20161013|title=Decade of Excellence Award: Michael Spencer, Group CEO, Icap|date=October 12, 2016|publisher=fnlondon.com}} == Personal life == In 2008, Spencer divorced his first wife Lorraine.{{cite web|url=https://www.standard.co.uk/news/city-tycoon-michael-spencers-1bn-break-up-6832505.html|title=City tycoon Michael Spencer's £1bn break-up|author=|date=|website=standard.co.uk|accessdate=3 September 2018}}{{cite web|url=http://www.thisismoney.co.uk/money/markets/article-5536951/BIG-SHOT-WEEK-Multi-millionaire-Nex-founder-Michael-Spencer-62-loves-good-party.html|title=BIG SHOT OF THE WEEK: Multi-millionaire Nex founder Michael Spencer|author=|date=|website=thisismoney.co.uk|accessdate=3 September 2018}} They had two sons and a daughter, and homes in Notting Hill, Suffolk and Manhattan. In June 2016 Spencer married Sarah, Marchioness of Milford Haven in London. Spencer has homes in Chelsea, London, and Kenya.{{cite web|url=http://www.thetimes.co.uk/article/yes-im-a-bit-of-barrow-boy-says-camerons-broker-buddy-n2s9ln5nd|title=Yes, I'm a bit of barrow boy, says Cameron's broker buddy|last1=Duke|first1=Simon|date=November 27, 2016|publisher=thetimes.co.uk}} ''Who's Who'' lists his hobbies as running, riding, shooting, wine and art; he is also reported to be an aviation enthusiast.{{Cite journal|last=|first=|date=|title=Who's Who|url=http://www.ukwhoswho.com.ezproxy2.londonlibrary.co.uk/view/10.1093/ww/9780199540884.001.0001/ww-9780199540884-e-4000213|journal=|volume=|pages=|doi=10.1093/ww/9780199540884.001.0001/ww-9780199540884-e-4000213|via=}} Spencer runs a horse-breeding programme and plans to build a stable in Laikipia. His horse Freewheeler, a South African-bred filly, won the 2018 Kenya Derby at Ngong. He collects twentieth century and contemporary art, including the work of [[Pablo Picasso|Picasso]], [[Lucian Freud]] and [[Jack Vettriano]]. Spencer is a former shareholder and an associate director of [[Ipswich Town Football Club]].{{cite web|url=https://www.standard.co.uk/business/business-news/michael-spencer-profile-the-700-million-dealmaker-close-to-david-cameron-a3108751.html|title=Michael Spencer profile: The £700 million dealmaker close to David Cameron|last1=Goodway|first1=Nick|date=November 6, 2015|publisher=standard.co.uk}} He cites [[Michael Bloomberg]] as a business influence, and reportedly is friends with [[Elton John|Sir Elton John]], [[Chris Eubank]], [[Keren Woodward]] and [[Andrew Ridgeley]]. He is a Christian and churchgoer. Spencer is a member of [[White's]], as well as clubs at 5 Hertford Street and 67 Pall Mall.{{Cite news|url=https://moneyweek.com/profile-michael-spencer-of-icap/|title=Profile: Michael Spencer of Icap - MoneyWeek|date=2007-11-21|work=MoneyWeek|access-date=2018-03-15|language=en-GB}} He once left a £5,000 tip for restaurant staff at [[Scott's (restaurant)|Scotts]], after winning a bet with [[Richard Caring]] about the outcome of the 2015 UK General Election.{{Cite news|url=http://www.thisismoney.co.uk/money/markets/article-5536951/BIG-SHOT-WEEK-Multi-millionaire-Nex-founder-Michael-Spencer-62-loves-good-party.html|title=BIG SHOT OF THE WEEK: Multi-millionaire Nex founder Michael Spencer|work=This is Money|access-date=2018-04-16}} == References == {{Reflist|30em}} == External links == * [http://observer.guardian.co.uk/business/story/0,,1774169,00.html Profile in ''The Observer'' May 2006] * [http://www.icapcharityday.com ICAP Charity Day] * [http://www.theconservativefoundation.co.uk/ Conservative Party Foundation] * [http://beta.charitycommission.gov.uk/charity-details/?subid=0®id=1154930 Borana Conservation Trust] {{DEFAULTSORT:Spencer, Michael}} [[Category:20th-century British businesspeople]] [[Category:21st-century British businesspeople]] [[Category:Alumni of Corpus Christi College, Oxford]] [[Category:British financial businesspeople]] [[Category:British financiers]] [[Category:English financial businesspeople]] [[Category:British company founders]] [[Category:British technology company founders]] [[Category:British investors]] [[Category:British venture capitalists]] [[Category:Charity fundraisers (people)]] [[Category:Conservative Party (UK) people]] [[Category:English businesspeople]] [[Category:English financial company founders]] [[Category:English philanthropists]] [[Category:Lists of people associated with the University of Oxford|Corpus Christi College, Oxford]] [[Category:People educated at Worth School| ]] [[Category:People educated by school in West Sussex]] [[Category:Philanthropists]]

{{multiple issues| {{lead rewrite|date=August 2012}} {{more citations needed|date=July 2012}} }} {{Infobox saint | name=Saint Misael the Anchorite | birth_date=7th century{{efn|Based on his youth in Anba Isaac's narrative,{{cite web |url=http://stsamuel.monastery.free.fr/index.php/saints/abba-misael-the-anchorite |website=St. Samuel Coptic Orthodox Monastery, Egypt |title=Abba Missael the Anchorite |author=Anba Isaac |access-date=21 August 2015}} and the consecration of the church at the end of the narrative in Coptic Year 396, corresponding to the Latin year 680}} | death_date=??? | feast_day= Month of [[Koiak]] 13 [[Coptic Orthodox Church of Alexandria|Coptic Church]] | venerated_in=[[Coptic Orthodox Church]],
[[Oriental Orthodoxy]], | image= | imagesize=185px | caption=A Coptic icon of St. Misael the Anchorite at St. Mary & St. Mark's Coptic Orthodox Centre in [[Birmingham]], [[United Kingdom]] | birth_place=[[Egypt]] | death_place= | titles=the Anchorite
the Holy Monk | beatified_date= | beatified_place= | beatified_by= | canonized_date= | canonized_place= | canonized_by= | attributes= | patronage= | major_shrine=Monastery of Saint [[Samuel the Confessor]], [[Mount Qalamoun]], Egypt | suppressed_date= | issues= | prayer= | prayer_attrib= }} Saint '''Misael the Anchorite''' was a Christian monk who is venerated by the [[Coptic Orthodox Church]]. ==Biography== Much of St. Misael's story is recorded by Anba Isaac, the abbot of the St. Samuel monastery. St. Misael is known to have had parents who were not religious or heavily involved with the church. His parents also struggled to have a child. It is said that an old monk gave commands to the father to return to the Church and to strengthen the family's foundation with the Christian faith so that they could have a child. According to the testimony of St. Misael to the abbot of St. Samuel monastery, it was after his father had done all that the elder monk had commanded that his mother gave birth to him. St. Misael was accepted into the monastery of St. [[Samuel the Confessor]] by the Abbot and was accordingly dressed with the garb of the monastic life and the holy Eskeem. From there on, he lived a solitary life in worship and asceticism. St. Misael is also said to have prophesied about three main events which took place. The first of which concerned an incoming famine; in response to hearing about this, the abbot of the monastery was able to purchase a plentiful supply of grain in preparation. The second prophesy concerned him being taken away from the monastery by a soldier. The third prophesy regarded St. Misael's own death: he informed the abbot of the monastery, Abba Isaac, that he would die the following year. After that, Isaac reports that Misael "departed and I did not see him again". ==Feast Day and Commemoration== The consecration day of the church of St. Misael was on the 10th of Bashens in the Coptic Year 396, during the reign of [[Decledianus]]. The Coptic Orthodox Church celebrates the feast of St. Misael on the 13th of the Month of [[Koiak]]. ==See also== * [[Bishop Missael]] of Birmingham ==Notes== {{notelist}} ==References== {{Reflist}} {{Authority control}} {{Coptic saints}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Anchorite, Misael the}} [[Category:Coptic Christians]] [[Category:Egyptian saints]] [[Category:Year of birth missing]] [[Category:Year of death missing]] [[Category:Egyptian Christian saints]] [[Category:Coptic Orthodox saints]] [[Category:Hermits]] [[Category:Egyptian Christian monks]] [[Category:396 births]]

[[Heroes Reborn (miniseries)|Heroes Reborn]] | image = [[Image:Noah Bennet.jpg|200px]] | caption = Jack Coleman as Noah Bennet | portrayer = [[Jack Coleman (actor)|Jack Coleman]] | first = "[[Genesis (Heroes)|Genesis]]"

(''Heroes Reborn'') | lbl21 = Ability |data21 = | children = [[Claire Bennet]] (adopted daughter/protegee)
