{{Use dmy dates|date=March 2018}} {{Use British English|date=March 2018}} '''Oliver Le Neve''' (1662 - November 1711) was a Norfolk [[Gentry|country squire]] and landowning sportsman who lived most of his life at Witchingham Hall in [[Great Witchingham]], [[Norfolk, England|Norfolk]], England, and is significant for his 1698 mortal [[duel]] with [[Sir Henry Hobart, 4th Baronet|Sir Henry Hobart]] of [[Blickling Hall]], the last recorded duel fought in Norfolk. ==Early life== Oliver Le Neve was born in 1662 to Francis Le Neve (d.1681), a London draper and upholsterer at [[Cornhill, London|Cornhill]], and Avice, his wife, who was daughter to city merchant Peter Wright. Francis Le Neve, who may have been brought to London by his Norfolk kinsman [[William Le Neve]], owned a modest amount of London property, warehouses and shops. Oliver Le Neve had an older brother, [[Peter Le Neve|Peter]], who became an [[Antiquarian|antiquary]], elected [[Antiquarian#London societies|President of the Antiquarian Society]] in 1687, and became a [[Norroy and Ulster King of Arms|Norroy King of Arms]] [[College of Arms|herald]].Betham, Rev. William (1804), ''The Baronetage of England, Or the History of the English Baronets'', vol. 4, p.297Rye, Walter; [https://en.wikisource.org/wiki/Le_Neve,_Peter_(DNB00) "Le Neve, Peter"] Dictionary of National Biography, 1885-1900, Volume 33. Retrieved 31 March 2018[https://books.google.com/books?id=NTLj3Y0knlIC&dq=le+neve+knights&printsec=frontcover&source=bl&ots=F8U5dGkPm4&sig=fhAWzTnRHnCLPIlDG7PgJ8jEHwk&hl=en&ei=g7xJS9abJIHQtgO0isnPBQ&sa=X&oi=book_result&ct=result&resnum=4&ved=0CBYQ6AEwAw#v=onepage&q=&f=false ''Le Neve's Pedigrees of the Knights Made by King Charles II, King James II, King William III and Queen Mary, King William Alone and Queen Anne''], George W. Marshall (ed.) [[Harleian Society]] (1873), preface p. v–ix Le Neve's immediate family originated in Norfolk, with the ancestral family dating there to at least the early 15th century, particularly at [[Ringland, Norfolk|Ringland]]; his grandfather Firmian Le Neve was the first from Ringland known to live in London.[[Adam Nicolson|Nicolson, Adam]] (2012); ''Gentry: Six Hundred Years of a Peculiarly English Class'', Part III: The Great Century 1610-1710, "Honour: The le Neves, Great Witchingham, Norfolk", [[HarperCollins]]. {{ISBN|0007335504}}Rye, Francis, Rye, Amy; ''Calendar of Correspondence and Documents Relating to the Family of Oliver Le Neve, of Witchingham, Norfolk, 1675-1743'', Norwich, A. H. Goose, (1895). Reprint Rarebooksclub.com (2012). {{ISBN|1130313972}}[https://web.archive.org/web/20170322080204/http://www.leneve.com:80/chapter3.htm "Chapter 3: OLiver Le Neve"] ''The Le Neve's of Norfolk'', Leneve.com, [[Wayback Machine]], 22 March 2017. Retrieved 31 March 2018 An older half-cousin twice removed of Le Neve, also called Oliver Le Neve (c.1600 - 1678) of Great Witchingham, who had been a stationer in London, willed in 1674 everything to his 10-year-old namesake, leaving the brother Peter as the recipient of the [[bequest]] if Oliver died without male heir.''Reports of Cases Argued and Determined in the High Court of Chancery in the time of Lord Chancellor Hardwicke'' (1782), Ed. John Tracy Atkyns, vol. 3, pp.26,27 The settlement left Le Neve wealthy and the owner of Witchingham Hall, with his income being augmented by rent from his properties in London. Le Neve was sent to [[Hart Hall]] at [[University of Oxford|Oxford]] in 1679-80, and later in life became a local [[Justice of the peace|magistrate]] and captain of the local [[Militia#16th and 17th centuries|militia]]. ==Marriage and Witchingham Hall== [[File:Great Witchingham Hall (geograph 3935879) optimized and spun.jpg|thumb|right|Great Witchingham Hall]] In 1684 Le Neve married Anne Gawdy (1656 - 1696), who was from a further Norfolk [[gentry]] family at [[Harling, Norfolk|West Harling]], typically of lawyers and MPs. Anne Gawdy was granddaughter to Sir [[William Gawdy]] (1612–1669), who was an MP in the [[Cavalier Parliament]], and who had bought his [[baronet]]cy in 1663. Anne died in 1696 after producing two boys, one of whom died in 1689 in infancy, and three girls. Le Neve was a strong friend to Bassingbourne, Anne's brother, until his death of [[smallpox]]. He renovated and replanted gardens at Witchingham Hall, with plants, particularly fruit, he bought from local contacts, or in London and transported through the port of [[Great Yarmouth]] from the [[River Thames|Thames]]. He shipped additional London purchases under personal request of the Gawdy family, particularly painting materials for the painter and brother of Bassingbourne, [[John Gawdy]] who succeeded to the Gawdy baronetcy as the 2nd Baronet.Goodwin, Gordon; [https://en.wikisource.org/wiki/Gawdy,_John_(DNB00) "Gawdy, John"] Dictionary of National Biography, 1885-1900, Volume 21. Retrieved 31 March 2018 Le Neve became a popular and social focus for young [[Tory]] [[squire]]s, the sons of [[English Civil War|Civil War]] [[cavalier]]s, with Witchingham Hall becoming a centre for convivial hospitality, and animosity towards the [[Whigs (British political party)|Whigs]] in power and the [[Court (royal)|court]]. The pastimes he and his friends favoured were hunting with [[beagle]]s, shooting, fishing, and horse racing at [[Newmarket Racecourse|Newmarket]]. Through these he became close friends with John (Jack) Millecent, a [[Rake (stock character)|rakish]] squire from [[Linton, Cambridgeshire]], whose family also shared mutual animosity with their local Whigs. By 1894 Millecent had persuaded Le Neve to breed and keep his own beagle pack, sold to him by Millecent who later stated was "the finest pack of Beagles in England". The growing reputation of Le Neve's pack in 1697 prompted [[Pettus baronets#Sir Horatio Pettus, the 4th Baronet|Sir Horatio Pettus]] Bt. to beg a hound off him, one of a number sold to members of the Norfolk gentry. In 1707, after hunting hare and fox in Norfolk, Essex and Surrey, Le Neve sold his pack, only to buy another soon after. Le Neve was a collector of ribald verse penned by his Witchingham Hall circle of friends which he edited and gathered into a folio miscellany, and which today is kept by [[Chetham's Library]] in [[Manchester]]. Some verses were by Le Neve himself, with titles such as 'Madam as victors when they quit the field', 'Tell me insipid lecher now the tide', and 'When Lydia thou the rosy neck and arms'.[http://artsonline.monash.edu.au/llcl/clandestine-satire/mc14/ "Manchester, Chetham’s Library, MS Mum. A4.14 (Mc14)"], [[Monash University]] School of Languages, Literatures, Cultures and Linguistics. Retrieved 31 March 2018 After the death of Le Neve's wife Anne, Millecent promoted a match with Jane Knyvet (b.1670), referred to as one of the "[[Darsham]] Ladies" of [[Suffolk]], and the fourth daughter to Sir John Knyvet of [[Ashwellthorpe and Fundenhall|Ashwellthorpe]]; Le Neve married her in 1698. ==Election and animosity== Le Neve was frequently at odds with, and slighted by, Norfolk higher [[Landed gentry|gentry]] who tended to be Whigs and supporters of [[William III of England|William III]]. A particular earlier slight was the patronizing attitude of Thomas Browne of [[Elsing|Elsing Hall]] over the 22-year-old Le Neve's trade ("mircatorian") family background. This animosity came to a head during the [[English general election, 1698|election year of 1698]]. [[Sir Henry Hobart, 4th Baronet|Sir Henry Hobart]] [[Member of parliament#United Kingdom of Great Britain and Northern Ireland|MP]] of Blickling Hall was "the undisputed leader of Norfolk Whigs",Handley, S. (2002); [http://www.historyofparliamentonline.org/volume/1690-1715/member/hobart-sir-henry-1657-98 "HOBART, Sir Henry, 4th Bt. (c.1657-98), of Blickling Hall, Norf"], [[History of Parliament Online]], using text from ''The History of Parliament: the House of Commons 1690-1715'', ed. D. Hayton, E. Cruickshanks. Retrieved 31 March 2018 and an influential operator of [[Whiggism|Whig patronage]] of government, public office and county favours, part of a perceived corrupt regime that excluded Le Neve and his fellow Tories. The election was, however, a turning point for Hobart, a sitting MP. Three candidates contended for two positions: Sir Henry (Whig), [[Cooke baronets#Cooke baronets, of Brome Hall|Sir William Cooke]] (Tory), and Sir Jacob Astley (Whig). Hobart lost after spending a considerable sum to ensure his seat. In the heightened atmosphere surrounding the election, rumours were circulating about Hobart, particularly concerning his growing debts and creditors, and one that Le Neve was saying Hobart was a coward, especially during 1689-90 when he was [[Gentleman of the Horse]] for William III while [[Battle of the Boyne|campaigning in Ireland]], and it was this poor reputation cost him the election. Le Neve denied the accusation. Hobart, who believed Le Neve was instrumental in his defeat, publicly accused him of spreading the rumour—this in the market square at [[Reepham, Norfolk|Reepham]] in Le Neve's absence—and that the only reason he denied it was that he was too afraid to fight. Le Neve wrote to Hobart asserting again his innocence, but offering to [[duel|give satisfaction]] to whomever had spread the rumour, saying if Hobart could not supply the name of the culprit, he would assume it was "Blickling" (code for Hobart himself) that was generating this quarrel, and that he would meet him at his choosing. An appointment was made for the duel. ==Duel and aftermath== [[Duel]]s had been [[Tacit assumption|tacitly]] assumed illegal since a 1614 edict by [[James I of England|James I]], but often a blind eye was turned. However, prosecution for duelling was a possibility, especially if no seconds or witnesses were present to assure fair play. [[Adam Nicolson]] in his book ''Gentry: Six Hundred Years of a Peculiarly English Class'' conjectures that despite this, the reason Hobart and Le Neve refused seconds was conversely to avoid any witness for possible prosecution. Some sources suggest that a young servant girl witnessed the duel from nearby bushes;Briggs, Stacia; Connor, Siofra; [http://www.edp24.co.uk/news/weird-norfolk-the-cawston-duel-stone-and-a-ghost-of-blickling-hall-1-5244880 "Weird Norfolk: The Cawston duel stone and a ghost of Blickling Hall"], ''[[Eastern Daily Press]]'', 20 October 2017. Retrieved 31 March 2018 reliable sources either don't mention this, or if they do, treat it as [[folklore]]. The duel took place on [[Cawston, Norfolk|Cawston Heath]] on 20 August 1698. Both men rode from their respective seats: Hobart from Blickling {{convert|4|mi|km|0}} to the northeast, and Le Neve from Witchingham 4 miles to the southwest. During the duel the left-handed Le Neve was apparently struck in the arm and replied with a thrust to the belly. The mortally wounded Hobart returned to Blickling Hall, died the following day and was buried in the Blickling family vault. [[File:Duel stone at Cawston.jpg|right|thumb|right|Duel memorial at Cawston]] [[Narcissus Luttrell]], parliamentary diarist, heard that Le Neve "was wounded in the arm and Sir Henry run into the belly" The antiquary [[John Bowyer Nichols|John Nichols]] in 1812 stated that le Neve wasn't struck as Hobart's sword thrust was caught in a [[greatcoat]] Le Neve was wearing. Adam Nicolson believes these accounts say more about class attitudes towards the differences in the backgrounds of the two men: the rapier of the elegant swordsmanship of the grand gentry in its finery aiming for the arm and being tangled in the coarse cloth of the minor gentry, which replies with a stab to the belly. However Nicolson is sceptical, believing that as a captain of militia Le Neve would be more than skillful in refined use of sword, and on a possibly hot August day, would prefer not to be encumbered by a greatcoat. Le Neve decided to escape the area, concerned over repercussions of killing a Whig of such high rank. A £500 reward for capture was offered by Lady Hobart. The armed [[Norfolk Militia]] was set to look for him, some searching the Gawdy house at West Harling. From London, Le Neve left for [[Rotterdam]], although occasionally returning incognito to London, where he was once nearly captured. He kept in touch with his family and friends who offered advice to avoid capture and provided Norfolk comestibles, he sending goods back from Holland. While on his travels and in Rotterdam he adopted the aliases of 'Davyes', 'Captain Janszen', and 'Mr Browne, the sword cutler'. He received a visit from his wife Jane in 1699. In [[East Anglia]] Le Neve was a hero and martyr for Tories, while the Whigs wanted him outlawed if he didn't return to face trial. His friends tried to arrange a [[sheriff]] and jury who would be, to their mind, honest and responsible. He returned and went on trial at [[Thetford]] [[assizes]] in 1700, was found not guilty, and returned to Witchingham. After Jane died in 1704, and was buried at St Mary's Church, Jack Millecent again turned matchmaker for Le Neve. He secured a further marriage on 31 July 1707 to Elizabeth (b.1678), daughter to his friend Robert Sheffield who was the grandson to the [[Earl of Mulgrave#Earls of Mulgrave, first creation|Earl of Musgrave]]; she was one of two eligible Sheffield sisters presented by Millecent. Three months later Elizabeth died. Following the duel, Lady Hobart erected a memorial stone plinth with urn at the site. Today the plinth is a Grade II [[listed building|listed]] structure.[https://historicengland.org.uk/services-skills/education/educational-images/the-duel-stone-holt-road-cawston-9163 The Duel Stone, Holt Road, Cawston, Norfolk]. [[Historic England]]. Retrieved 31 March 2018{{NHLE| num=1050952 |desc=The Duel Stone |grade=II |accessdate=31 March 2018}} ==Death== Oliver Le Neve died on 23 November 1711 at West Harling, and was buried with his first wife Anne Gawdy at Great Witchingham. As his sons predeceased him, his estate passed to his elder brother Peter until his death in 1729, who in his will intended the estate to pass to his three nieces, Le Neve's daughters. However, after legal battles, with accusations by the Le Neves of conflict interest, the estate was taken through reversion of the will by the trustees of a John Norris, whose grandfather, a [[Norwich]] lawyer of the same name, had acted as trustee for the young Oliver Le Neve. The three daughters of Le Neve were ejected from the estate.Bellhouse, David R. (2017); ''Leases for Lives: Life Contingent Contracts and the Emergence of Actuarial Science in Eighteenth-Century England'' [[Cambridge University Press]], p.69. {{ISBN|1107111765}}Parkin, Rev. Charles; (1808) ''An essay towards a topographical history of the county of Norfolk'' vol, 3; p.300 (reversion of Peter Le Neve will), p.308 (Oliver Le Neve church monument)Blomefield, Francis; [http://www.british-history.ac.uk/topographical-hist-norfolk/vol8/pp297-311. "Eynford Hundred: Witchingham, Magna and Parva."], ''An Essay Towards A Topographical History of the County of Norfolk'': Volume 8. London: W Miller, 1808. 297-311. [[British History Online]]. Retrieved 1 April 2018 These three surviving daughters by Anne Gawdy—Isabella, Anne and Henrietta—inherited the Gawdy estate at West Harling, and erected a chancel marble wall monument to their parents in St Mary's Church at Great Witchingham. The monument inscription reads:
Under the earth near this stone lyeth the dust of Oliver le Neve Esq late of this parish one of the Justices of the Peace and Captain of a Foot Company of the Militia of this County Second son of Frances le Neve gentleman Citizen and Draper of London and of Avice his wife daughter of Peter Wright and sister and heir of Peter Wright of London Merchant he died on the 23rd day of November Anno Domino 1711 and was buried on the 26th of the same month leaving behind him by his first wife Anne only ye daughter of Sir John Gaudy of West Herling in this County Baronet (who lyeth by his side) three daughters and co-heirs Isabella Anne and Henrietta Le Neve who caused this Memorial to be set up As also what remains of Elizabeth his second wife daughter and co-heir expectant of Robert Sheffield of Kensington in Middlesex Esq grandson of Edmund Earl of Mulgrave long since deceased she died suddenly on the 8th day of November 1707 without child and was buried here on the 12th day of the same month.
Tam Math quam Mercurio [''As much a man of war as commerce'']

{{Unreferenced|date=December 2008}} [[File:Caen museedesbeauxarts cpa gayrard.jpg|thumb|''[[Daphnis and Chloe]]'' by Raymond Gayrard, [[Musée des Beaux-Arts de Caen]]]] '''Paul Joseph Raymond Gayrard''' (3 September 1807 – 1855) was French sculptor born in [[Clermont-Ferrand]], France.
He studied at an early age under his sculptor/engraver father Raymond Gayrard, and was a student of [[Francois Rude]] as well as [[David d'Angers]].
Gayrard first exhibited his works at the Salon in 1827 and continued to submit works throughout his lifetime winning a Second class medal in 1834 and a First Class Medal in 1846 and 1848. His last recorded exhibit was in 1855. He was very successful among the more wealthy of French high society and executed many busts of the more notables of the day, but had a considerable talent for animal modeling. His known bronze animal models date from the years 1846 until 1848 with his powerful plaster of a 'Harness Horse' exhibited at the Salon in 1847 and submitted again in 1848 in bronze. Also in 1848 his bronze of a 'Reclining Deerhound', thought to be first viewed when in plaster at the Salon in 1846, was particularly striking. One of his other animals groups titled 'The Monkey Steeplechase' is a rather humorous and whimsical subject done in a similar vain to [[Christophe Fratin]]'s bronzes of [[humanized animals]].
His monumental works include the four evangelists for the [[Basilica of St. Clotilde, Paris|Sainte Clotide Basilica]] in Paris.

{{EngvarB|date=April 2015}} {{Use dmy dates|date=April 2015}} {{Infobox person | image = Richard bacon shirt.jpg | caption = Richard Bacon in 2010 | name = Richard Bacon | birth_name = Richard Paul Bacon | birth_date = {{Birth date and age|df=yes|1975|11|30}} | birth_place = [[Mansfield]], Nottinghamshire, England{{citation needed|date=November 2011}} | education = [[Worksop College]], [[Nottinghamshire]]
(independent boarding school) | alma_mater = [[Nottingham Trent University]] | death_date = | residence = [[Los Angeles]], [[California]], U.S. | occupation = television and radio presenter | yearsactive = 1993–present | spouse = Rebecca McFarlane (m. 2008) | children = Arthur Bacon (b. 2011)
Ivy Bacon (b. 2014) | parents = | website = | awards = }} '''Richard Paul Bacon''' (born 30 November 1975){{Cite web|url=http://www.bbc.co.uk/cult/classic/bluepeter/presenters/bacon.shtml |title=Richard Bacon |accessdate=16 February 2009 |last= |first= |date= |publisher=[[BBC Online]] }} is an English television and radio presenter. He was a host of the children's show ''[[Blue Peter]]''—his first high-profile media role—until he was fired in 1998 after 18 months for admitting to taking cocaine.[[Blue Peter#Controversy|Controversy]], [[Blue Peter]]. He has since worked as a reporter or presenter on numerous television shows, including ''[[The Big Breakfast]]'', and on radio stations including [[Capital London|Capital FM]], [[Xfm London]] and [[BBC Radio Five Live]]. In 2016 Bacon became the presenter of The [[National Geographic Channel]]'s reboot of its documentary/panel discussion TV series, ''[[Explorer (TV series)|Explorer]]''. ==Early life and education== Bacon grew up in [[Mansfield]], Nottinghamshire, and was educated at St Peter's Church of England Primary School on Bellamy Road, followed by two independent schools, also in Nottinghamshire: at Wellow House School, a [[Preparatory school (UK)|preparatory school]] on Newark Road in the village of [[Wellow, Nottinghamshire|Wellow]], and then at [[Worksop College]], a boarding school on Windmill Lane in the town of [[Worksop]]. He studied Business Studies with Electronics at [[Nottingham Trent University]], but dropped out after a year.{{Cite web |first=Richard |last=Bacon |title=Hello Oxford. Good to be back in the city where I got my 1st. Was either that or Notts Trent (for a year before dropping out). Can't recall. |format=Tweet |work=Twitter |url=https://twitter.com/richardpbacon/status/200955023063121920 |date=11 May 2012 |accessdate=13 May 2012}} ==Life and career== His first job in the media was as a reporter for [[BBC Radio Nottingham]], notably on the programme ''The Beat''. In February 1996 he joined [[L!VE TV]] as a reporter; this saw him being banned from the [[State Opening of Parliament]], and having a beer thrown at him by [[Damon Albarn]] as he tried to interview him leaving a nightclub. ===''Blue Peter''=== {{main|Blue Peter}} Bacon's television break was as a presenter on the children's show ''Blue Peter'', which he joined on 21 February 1997. He presented alongside [[Romana D'Annunzio]], [[Katy Hill]], [[Konnie Huq]] and [[Stuart Miles]]. On 19 October 1998 he was the programme's first-ever presenter to have his contract terminated in mid-season, after the tabloid newspaper ''[[News of the World]]'' published a report of Bacon taking [[cocaine]]. His tenure on the programme lasted just over 18 months. After his dismissal, the then Head of [[BBC]] children's programmes [[Lorraine Heggessey]] went on air to explain the situation to [[CBBC]] viewers. ===TV career since ''Blue Peter''=== Bacon's television career survived the setback, and he has since presented such shows as ''[[The Big Breakfast]]'', ''[[Top of the Pops]]'', and reality TV shows ''[[Back to Reality (TV series)|Back To Reality]]'' and ''[[Castaway 2007|Castaway Exposed]]''. In August 2005 the band [[The Magic Numbers]] walked out of ''Top of the Pops'', after Bacon made a remark that was widely thought to be about the body shape of members of the band; during rehearsals he referred to the band as a "big, fat melting pot of talent".{{Cite news| url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/entertainment/music/4135380.stm | work=BBC News | title=Rock band's fury at TV 'fat' quip | date=9 August 2005 | accessdate=22 May 2010}} Since 2006 he has narrated and presented [[BBC Three]]'s series ''[[Most Annoying People]]''. Bacon guest-hosted [[ITV (TV network)|ITV]]'s ''[[This Morning (TV programme)|This Morning]]'' during 2005, [[Channel 5 (UK)|Channel 5]]'s ''[[The Wright Stuff]]'' on several occasions during 2007 and 2008, and [[BBC Two]]'s ''[[Something for the Weekend (2000s BBC TV series)|Something for the Weekend]]'' from 2008 to 2009. He was the narrator for series 1 to 3 of [[BSkyB|Sky]]'s police documentary ''[[Brit Cops]]''. In late 2010 he presented ''[[Richard Bacon's Beer & Pizza Club]]'' on [[ITV4]].{{cite web|url=http://www.comedy.co.uk/guide/tv/beer_and_pizza_club/|title=Richard Bacon's Beer & Pizza Club|work=comedy.co.uk}} A second series aired in late 2011.{{Cite news| url=http://www.broadcastnow.co.uk/news/commissioning/itv4-tucks-into-richard-bacons-beer-and-pizza-club-again/5029170.article | work=Broadcast | title=ITV4 tucks into Richard Bacon's Beer & Pizza Club again | date=24 June 2011 | accessdate=22 September 2011}} Just before the [[2010 World Cup]] he hosted a show called ''World Cup's Most Shocking Moments'', with [[Peter Crouch]]. Bacon presented editions of BBC Three's ''[[Question Time (TV series)|Young Voters' Question Time]]''. He has made several TV [[cameo appearance]]s as himself, including ''[[Hotel Babylon]]'' in 2007 (in which his character hires [[Call girl|escort girls]] to play [[Scrabble]] with him all night), the episode "Video Killed the Radio Star" of the TV series ''[[FM (TV series)|FM]]'', an episode of ''[[The Thick of It]]'' (both in 2009) and an episode of ''[[Psychoville]]'' in 2011. In October 2011 he hosted BBC Three's ''Up for Hire'', an interactive series over the course of five nights tackling one of Britain's biggest issues – youth unemployment. In April 2012 he presented the [[Channel 4]] television series ''[[Hidden Talent]]'', where each programme featured ordinary members of the public taking tests in certain fields or skills to identify any previously unidentified talent.{{cite news| url=https://www.theguardian.com/tv-and-radio/2012/apr/24/hidden-talent-tv-review | location=London | work=The Guardian | first=Zoe | last=Williams | title=TV review: Hidden Talent | date=24 April 2012}} On 25 November 2013 Bacon hosted one series of ITV's game show ''[[Show Me the Telly]]''. On 8 December 2013 he guest-presented an episode of ''[[Sunday Scoop]]''. On 17 February 2014 he hosted a one-off show, ''Benefits Britain: The Debate'', for Channel 4. In 2014 he presented the live Channel 4 programme ''How Rich Are You?'', about the UK economy. In 2015, Bacon co-presented the first series of ''[[The Big Painting Challenge]]'' alongside [[Una Stubbs]] for [[BBC One]], and sports show ''Eternal Glory'' for ITV. He also joined [[Reena Ninan]] as a substitute co-host of the [[American Broadcasting Company]]'s ''[[World News Now]]'' overnight and ''[[America This Morning]]'' news program.{{cite web|url=https://twitter.com/richardpbacon/status/673756241794113536|title=richard bacon on Twitter|publisher=}} Beginning on 14 November 2016, the U.S. worldwide educational cable network [[National Geographic Channel]] (hereinafter NGC) debuted its "global" overhaul and rebranding of the channel with its entirely new primetime lineup that night: the much-anticipated, multi-million U.S.-dollar docudrama miniseries ''[[Mars (miniseries)|Mars]]'', followed by the NGC reboot of ''[[Explorer (TV series)|Explorer]]'', and then ''[[StarTalk (2015 TV series)|Star Talk]]'', a lighthearted panel-discussion series loosely centered around [[astrophysics]] and [[astronomy]], hosted by astrophysicist Dr. [[Neil DeGrasse Tyson]]. Bacon became the presenter for the ''[[Explorer (TV series)|Explorer]]'' programme, which comprises several (usually three [3]) short films, introduced by Bacon and shot from all over the world, involving matters of social, political, environmental, and/or humanitarian significance. Each film is then discussed before a live studio audience with Bacon moderating and usually includes the filmmaker or another representative of the film. Then, at least one expert on either side of the issue also joins the discussion. The live-audience segments of each episode of ''Explorer'' are filmed at [[Columbia Broadcasting System|CBS]] [[Studios]] in [[New York City]]. For the debut show, Bacon hiked through [[Yosemite National Park]] with [[President of the United States|President]] [[Barack Obama]].{{cite web|url=http://news.nationalgeographic.com/2016/06/president-obama-yosemite-national-parks-climate-conservation/|title=Exclusive: Obama on Threats to Nature, Power of National Parks|author=|date=18 June 2016|website=nationalgeographic.com}} In June 2017, he began hosting a daily half hour newsmagazine show called ''[["Top 30"]]''.{{cite web|url=http://top-30.com/|title=Top30 Website|first=Top|last=30|date=|website=Fox Top30}} it originally aired on Fox affiliates for four weeks before being picked up as a regular series, broadcast nationally across America, in September 2017. On September 13, 2017, it was renewed through 2019.[[url]]https://tvseriesfinale.com/tv-show/top-30-news-tv-show-renewed-2019-fox-stations/[[/url]] ===Radio career=== Bacon joined [[BBC Radio 5 Live]] to present the late-night show on Saturdays and Sundays. After this, he worked as an announcer for [[BBC 7]] and then a DJ for [[Capital London|Capital FM]] followed by [[Xfm London]]. He returned to 5 Live, and from November 2007 until December 2009 presented the late-night programme, in which his sign-off ("Goodnight Great Britain, wherever you are") copied that of Jack Killian, the main character in the [[NBC]] television series ''[[Midnight Caller]]''. He also on occasion stood in for [[Simon Mayo]] in the daytime film review programme, and stated that his favourite film is ''[[The Apartment]]''. In January 2010 Bacon became the regular presenter of the 5 Live mid-afternoon show from Mondays to Thursdays, where he replaced the departing Simon Mayo. The show covered news, sport, celebrity interviews and special features. On Tuesdays there was a TV review with Boyd Hilton and another guest, looking back over the week's television and previewing future programmes. In the Moan-In on Wednesdays, listeners could share their moans and receive marks out of 10 from Bacon and a guest, often [[Dave Vitty]]. On Thursdays the feature was Chart The Week, where two guests would discuss the week's most talked-about news stories. At the same time, Bacon started to present a regular Saturday afternoon show on [[BBC Radio 6 Music]]; he later left to concentrate on other commitments. He returned to 6 Music in January 2012 for six weeks to present a Saturday morning programme. Bacon's afternoon show attracted criticism for its content, which was classified by the [[BBC Trust]] as "news". Rival broadcaster [[Talksport]] made a general complaint in 2010 to the BBC Trust, claiming the BBC Radio 5 Live station was not providing its mandatory 75% news output, "with many items falling outside of the remit, such as 'entertainment-based interviews' ... and listener-generated features."{{cite web |title=BBC Trust dismisses 5 Live news complaint |accessdate=22 September 2011 |date=15 April 2011 |publisher=Digital Spy |first=Andrew |last=Laughlin|url=http://www.digitalspy.co.uk/broadcasting/news/a314768/bbc-trust-dismisses-5-live-news-complaint.html}} Talksport's complaint "particularly singl[ed] out Bacon's two-hour weekday afternoon show for criticism",{{cite web |title=Richard Bacon defends Radio 5 Live output |accessdate=22 September 2011 |date=16 May 2011 |publisher=Digital Spy |author=Andrew Laughlin|url=http://www.digitalspy.co.uk/broadcasting/news/a319860/richard-bacon-defends-radio-5-live-output.html}} finding in a poll that only 20% of listeners considered Bacon's show to comprise "news". In their response, the BBC Trust rejected Talksport's complaints, but admitted that a review was required to develop "'a more nuanced method of monitoring the proportion of news output' on 5 Live compared to the current system, which counts the whole of Richard Bacon's afternoon show as news".{{cite news |title=Radio 5 Live to face closer scrutiny after TalkSport complaint |date=15 April 2011 |newspaper=The Guardian |first=John |last=Plunkett |accessdate=22 September 2011 |url=https://www.theguardian.com/media/2011/apr/15/radio-5-talksport-complaint |location=London}}{{cite news |title=TalkSport poll: Radio 5 Live should focus on serious news |date=20 April 2011 |newspaper= The Guardian |first=John |last=Plunkett |accessdate=22 September 2011 |url=https://www.theguardian.com/media/2011/apr/20/talksport-poll-radio-5-live-news |location=London}} In August 2011 Bacon recommended that his listeners should watch a [[YouTube]] video of comedian [[Doug Stanhope]], in which he mocked [[Sarah Palin]]'s disabled son Trig. The [[Down's Syndrome Association]] complained to the BBC about the broadcast, stating "the association is shocked that a BBC employee has publicised the work of a comedian which is nothing more than a vile offensive rant." Both Bacon and the BBC apologised for the broadcast, with Bacon writing "I full well understand my responsibilities as a broadcaster and such a reference fell below the standards I set myself personally in my broadcasting."{{cite web |first=Roy |last=Martin|url=http://radiotoday.co.uk/2011/08/richard-bacon-says-sorry-for-youtube-link/ |title=Richard Bacon says sorry for YouTube link |work=Radio Today |accessdate=13 May 2012}} On 1 July 2014 it was announced that Bacon would be leaving BBC Radio 5 Live later in the year.{{cite web|url=https://www.theguardian.com/media/2014/jul/01/bbc-radio-5-live-richard-bacon-leave-victoria-derbyshire-shelagh-fogarty|title=BBC Radio 5 Live stars including Richard Bacon to leave station|author=John Plunkett|work=the Guardian}} Bacon's last Radio 5 Live show was broadcast on 24 September 2014. Bacon also has covered for Simon Mayo on his [[BBC Radio 2]] Drivetime show, when Mayo was on holiday in August 2015, and more recently in April 2016. ===Personal life=== Bacon married Rebecca McFarlane in 2008. They live in [[Los Angeles]], where Bacon works in [[Television of United States|U.S. television]].{{cite web|url=https://www.theguardian.com/media/2015/apr/19/richard-bacon-david-frost-america-tv-nate-silver|title=Richard Bacon: 'My ambition is to be an unsuccessful David Frost'|author=John Plunkett|work=the Guardian}} His father-in-law is [[John McFarlane]], currently serving as chairman of [[Barclays]].{{cite web|url=https://www.ft.com/content/0c16762e-3a5a-11e4-8ee4-00144feabdc0|title=Subscribe to read|author=|date=|website=Financial Times}} On 31 October 2011 his wife gave birth to a son, Arthur and a daughter, Ivy, in 2014.{{citation needed|date=May 2016}} In October 2011 Bacon announced on his podcast that he had been contacted by the [[Metropolitan Police]], who advised him that his phone had been hacked by the private investigator [[Glenn Mulcaire]]. On 28 March 2018 Bacon explained to [[Nicky Campbell]] in an interview with [[BBC Radio 5 Live]] that at the age of 42 he was diagnosed with [[Attention deficit hyperactivity disorder]] (ADHD) which he said is “I like having it a lot, it is who I am. It’s just learning to work with it and manage it means that life gets less chaotic and painful for my wife and children”{{cite news|title=Richard Bacon: 'I wouldn't change my ADHD for the world’|url=http://www.bbc.co.uk/programmes/p062kr6l|date=28 March 2018|accessdate=28 March 2018|work=BBC Radio 5|agency=BBC}} In July 2018, he was placed in an [[induced coma]], after becoming ill with [[pneumonia]].{{cite web|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/uk-england-44818526 |title=Richard Bacon in induced coma after infection |work=BBC News |accessdate=13 July 2018}}{{cite news |title=Richard Bacon: Bug left me close to death for two days |url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/uk-england-nottinghamshire-44916454 |accessdate=25 July 2018 |work=BBC News |date=22 July 2018}} ===Charity=== Bacon was a celebrity supporter of the [[British Red Cross]] and is particularly interested in their National Flood Appeal and international messaging services.{{cite web |url=http://www.redcross.org.uk/standard.asp?id=80102 |title=Richard Bacon |work=British Red Cross |accessdate=13 June 2017 |deadurl=bot: unknown |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20090208035040/http://www.redcross.org.uk/standard.asp?id=80102 |archivedate=8 February 2009 |df=dmy-all }} ==References== {{Reflist|30em}} ==External links== {{pp-pc1}} {{Use mdy dates|date=October 2018}} {{Infobox officeholder |name = Robert Aderholt |image = Robert Aderholt official photo.jpg |state = [[Alabama]] |district = {{ushr|AL|4|4th}} |term_start = January 3, 1997 |term_end = |predecessor = [[Tom Bevill]] |successor = |birth_name=Robert Brown Aderholt |birth_date = {{birth date and age|1965|7|22}} |birth_place = [[Haleyville, Alabama|Haleyville]], [[Alabama]], U.S. |death_date = |death_place = |party = [[Republican Party (United States)|Republican]] |spouse = {{marriage|Caroline McDonald|1994}} |education = [[University of North Alabama]]
[[Birmingham–Southern College]]
([[Bachelor of Arts|BA]])
[[Samford University]] ([[Juris Doctor|JD]]) }} '''Robert Brown Aderholt'''[https://web.archive.org/web/20050223001027/http://csd.cqpress.com/Elections/house_mem/h0041.html U.S. House of Representatives] (born July 22, 1965) is the [[United States House of Representatives|U.S. Representative]] for {{ushr|Alabama|4|}}, serving since 1997. He is a member of the [[Republican Party (United States)|Republican Party]]. The district includes most of [[Tuscaloosa County]] north of the [[Black Warrior River]], as well as the far northern suburbs of [[Birmingham, Alabama|Birmingham]] in [[Walker County, Alabama|Walker County]] and the southern suburbs of [[Huntsville, Alabama|Huntsville]] and [[Decatur, Alabama|Decatur]]. Aderholt is a member of the congressional [[Tea Party Caucus]] and has taken conservative stands on issues such as abortion, tax reform, and defense spending.{{cite news |first=Mary |last=Orndorff Troyan |publisher=[[AL.com]] |title=Alabama Rep. Robert Aderholt joins congressional Tea Party Caucus |url=http://blog.al.com/sweethome/2010/08/alabama_rep_robert_aderholt_jo.html |date=August 4, 2010 |accessdate=September 5, 2014}} == Early life, education and career == Aderholt was born in Haleyville, Alabama, to Mary Frances Brown and Bobby Ray Aderholt.{{Cite web |url=http://familytreemaker.genealogy.com/users/e/l/l/John-C-Elliott/GENE4-0006.html|title=John-C-Elliott - User Trees - Genealogy.com |website=familytreemaker.genealogy.com|access-date=May 20, 2018}} Aderholt's father, a part-time minister for a small group of [[Congregational church|Congregational]] churches in northwest Alabama, was a circuit judge for more than 30 years. He attended the [[University of North Alabama]] and then [[Birmingham-Southern College]] from which he graduated. During college, Aderholt was a member of [[Kappa Alpha Order]]. Aderholt received his [[Juris Doctor|J.D.]] from the [[Samford University]] [[Cumberland School of Law]] and practiced law after graduation. In 1992, Aderholt was appointed Haleyville municipal judge.{{cite book |title=2014 Almanac of American Politics |last2=Barone |first2=Chuck |last1=McCutcheon|first1=Michael |publisher=The University of Chicago Press |year= 2013}} In the same year, he was a delegate to the Republican National Convention. In 1995, he became the top aide to [[Governor of Alabama|Governor]] [[Fob James]]. He won the 1996 Republican primary in the race to succeed 15-term [[United States Democratic Party|Democratic]] incumbent [[Tom Bevill]]. ==U.S. House of Representatives== ===Committee assignments=== * '''[[United States House Committee on Appropriations|Committee on Appropriations]]''' ** [[United States House Appropriations Subcommittee on Agriculture, Rural Development, Food and Drug Administration, and Related Agencies|Subcommittee on Agriculture, Rural Development, Food and Drug Administration, and Related Agencies]] (Chairman) ** [[United States House Appropriations Subcommittee on Commerce, Justice, Science, and Related Agencies|Subcommittee on Commerce, Justice, Science, and Related Agencies]] * '''[[Commission on Security and Cooperation in Europe]]''' ===Caucuses=== * [[Republican Study Committee]] * [[Tea Party Caucus]] * [[Congressional Caucus on Turkey and Turkish Americans]] * [[Congressional NextGen 9-1-1 Caucus]]{{cite web|title=Members|url=http://www.ng911institute.org/about-the-congressional-nextgen-9-1-1-caucus|publisher=Congressional NextGen 9-1-1 Caucus|accessdate=June 11, 2018}} *[[United States Congressional International Conservation Caucus]]{{cite web|title=Our Members |url=https://royce.house.gov/internationalconservation/members.html|publisher=U.S. House of Representatives International Conservation Caucus|accessdate=August 1, 2018}} ===Bills sponsored=== '''Sponsor HR 3808: Interstate Recognition of Notarizations Act of 2010, 111th Congress''' The bill was cosponsored by Reps. [[Bruce Braley]] (D., Iowa), [[Mike Castle|Michael Castle]] (R., Del.), and [[Artur Davis]] (D., Ala.). H.R. 3808 Interstate Recognition of Notarizations Act of 2010 – To require any Federal or State court to recognize any notarization made by a notary public licensed by a State other than the State where the court is located when such notarization occurs in or affects interstate commerce. April 27, 2010: This bill passed in the House of Representatives by voice vote. A record of each representative's position was not kept. September 27, 2010: This bill passed in the Senate by Unanimous Consent. A record of each senator's position was not kept. October 8, 2010: Vetoed by President. '''H.R. 2017 Continuing Appropriations Act, 2012''' May 26, 2011: Introduced June 2, 2011: Passed House with amendments September 26, 2011: Passed Senate with amendments September 30, 2011: Became Public Law 112-33{{Cite web|url=http://thomas.loc.gov/cgi-bin/bdquery/D?d112:2:./temp/~bd6HbH:@@@D&summ1&%7C/bss/|title=Congress.gov {{!}} Library of Congress|website=thomas.loc.gov|language=en|access-date=May 20, 2018}} ==Political campaigns== As the Republican nominee, Aderholt faced a considerable challenge against State Senator Bob Wilson Jr., who called himself a Democrat "in the [[Tom Bevill]] tradition". This was a seriously contested race, receiving a deal of national coverage and significant support from the Republican Party. [[Newt Gingrich]] personally visited the district during the campaign. Aderholt won narrowly, 50%–48%, becoming only the second Republican to represent this district since Reconstruction. The first, [[James D. Martin|Jim Martin]], was swept into office in what was then the 7th District during the 1964 wave that delivered the state's electoral votes to [[Barry Goldwater]]. Aderholt has never faced another contest nearly that close, and has been reelected nine times. He even ran unopposed in 2004, 2010, 2014, and 2016. Aderholt's increasing margins reflected the growing Republican trend in this part of Alabama. While Democrats still have a majority in voter registration, the district's Democrats are very conservative on social issues, even by Alabama standards. With a [[Cook Partisan Voting Index]] of R+30, it is the fifth-most Republican district in the nation and the third-most Republican district east of the Mississippi. ===2010 campaign=== {{See also|United States House of Representatives elections in Alabama, 2010#District 4}} ===2012 campaign=== {{further|United States House of Representatives elections in Alabama, 2012#District 4}} Aderholt was reelected in the November election where he beat [[Alabama House of Representatives|State representative]] [[Daniel Boman]], the Democratic nominee.{{cite web|title=Alabama Secretary of State |url=http://www.sos.state.al.us/downloads/election/2012/primary/Primary_Results_Certified-Democratic-2012-03-22.pdf|deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120911125014/http://www.sos.state.al.us/downloads/election/2012/primary/Primary_Results_Certified-Democratic-2012-03-22.pdf|archivedate=September 11, 2012}} In 2012 Aderholt raised $1,207,484.98 for his campaign, but spent only $963,859.15. Parker Towing was his largest contributor, providing $24,000.00. $493,856, 41% of his contributions came from large individual contributions. $583,000, 48% came from PACs.{{sfn|VoteSmart|2012}} ==Political positions== ===Defense spending=== He does not support reducing the defense budget to close the [[United States public debt|American deficit]], and in May 2012 said "cuts to defense budgets – the federal government's primary Constitutional responsibility – shouldn't be the relief valve for uncontrolled domestic program spending".{{cite web|title=Redstone's Pivotal Role in Nation's Technology Must be Protected, says Rep. Robert Aderholt |url=http://aderholt.house.gov/common/popup/popup.cfm?action=item.print&itemID=1435 |publisher=AL.com |accessdate=November 19, 2012}} ===Environmental issues=== During the 2013 111th Congress, Aderholt voted for the amendment by Rep. Scalise (R-LA)H. Amendment: H.Amdt. 448 to H.R. 367 which would "require that Congress be allowed to vote on any executive regulation that would impose any tax, price, or levy upon carbon emissions... effectively prevents the executive branch from levying any form of carbon tax without Congressional approval. Since a carbon tax would be tremendously destructive to the economy as a whole, this measure would hopefully make such a tax unlikely to pass."{{sfn|Freedom Works|2013}} Aderholt opposed regulations on greenhouse gas emissions, and in December 2008 helped write a letter to the [[U.S. Environmental Protection Agency]] (EPA) which stated, "I am opposed to any attempt to impose greenhouse gas regulations under the Clean Air Act on the agricultural industry."{{cite web|title=Inhofe Says EPA's New Boiler Rule Could Kill Nearly 800,000 Manufacturing Jobs|url=http://www.foxnews.com/politics/2010/09/28/inhofe-says-epas-new-boiler-rule-kill-nearly-manufacturing-jobs/|publisher=Fox News|accessdate=November 19, 2012|date=September 28, 2010}} Aderholt was against the policies promoted by the [[Copenhagen Climate Change Conference]] as well as the US proposed Cap and Trade Bill, part of what he argued was an "unrealistic carbon emissions reduction mandate" that would result in a loss of American jobs. He agreed with the global warming petition project{{citation|url=http://www.petitionproject.org/|title=Global warming petition project|publisher=Global warming petition project|accessdate=September 21, 2013}} that, "[t]here is no convincing scientific evidence that human release of carbon dioxide, methane, or other greenhouse gases is causing, or will in the foreseeable future, cause catastrophic heating of the Earth's atmosphere and disruption of the Earth's climate."{{sfn|Aderhodt|2010}} ===Gun policy=== Aderholt is a supporter of [[Gun politics in the United States|gun rights]]. He was endorsed by the [[National Rifle Association]] in the 2010 general election,{{cite web|title=Obama to present gun agenda; all but one Alabama representative supported by NRA |url=http://www.ontheissues.org/house/Robert_Aderholt_Gun_Control.htm|publisher=On The Issues|accessdate=November 19, 2012}} and received $2,000 from them.{{cite web|title=Robert Aderholt on Gun Control |url=http://blog.al.com/wire/2013/01/national_rifle_association_bac.html|publisher=Challen Stevens|accessdate=August 5, 2014}} In the wake of the [[2016 Orlando nightclub shooting]], Aderholt called it a [[terrorist attack]] and stated "we do not have the luxury of debating the political correctness of 'radical Islam'." He stated a need to "hunt down those who would do us harm." He opposed the media and President Obama using the shooting to "push any type of political agenda relating to [[gun control]]. He made a call to the White House and Congress to "protect the homeland."{{cite web|last1=Berkowitz|first1=Bonnie |last2=Cai|first2=Weiyi|last3=Lu|first3=Denise|last4=Gamio|first4=Lazaro|title=Everything lawmakers said (and didn't say) after the Orlando mass shooting|url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/graphics/national/how-lawmakers-responded-to-the-orlando-mass-shooting/ |website=Washington Post|accessdate=December 31, 2017}} === LGBT issues === Aderholt is opposed to [[same-sex marriage]]. He has received high ratings from the [[Family Research Council]], the [[Traditional Values Coalition]], and the [[American Family Association]].{{sfn|VoteSmart|2012}} In 2013, the [[Human Rights Campaign]] gave him a score of 0 on its Congressional Scorecard.{{cite web|title=Congressional Scorecard: Measuring Support for Equality in the 112th Congress|url=http://hrc-assets.s3-website-us-east-1.amazonaws.com//files/assets/resources/112thCongressionalScorecard_2012.pdf#__utma=149406063.1555353042.1407266521.1407266533.1407268463.3&__utmb=149406063.1.10.1407268463&__utmc=149406063&__utmx=-&__utmz=149406063.1407268463.3.3.utmcsr=google|publisher=Human Rights Campaign|accessdate=August 5, 2014}} ===Regulatory reform=== In December 2011, Aderholt voted in support of H.R. 10, the "Regulations From the Executive in Need of Scrutiny Act," which would have required congressional approval for any "major regulations" issued by the executive branch but, unlike the 1996 [[Congressional Review Act]], would not require the president's signature or override of a probable presidential veto.{{cite news |first=Felicia |last=Sonmez |newspaper=[[The Washington Post]] |title=REINS bill to expand congressional power over executive regulations passed by House |url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/blogs/2chambers/post/reins-bill-to-expand-congressional-power-over-executive-regulations-passed-by-house/2011/12/07/gIQAs6VMdO_blog.html |date=December 7, 2011 |accessdate=October 10, 2013}}{{cite web|title=FreedomWorks Scorecard|url=http://congress.freedomworks.org/legislators/robert-aderholt-0}} === Abortion === During the "[[March for Life (Washington, D.C.)|March for Life]]" rally in Washington on January 22, 2010, he said, "The issue of abortion and the sanctity of life is something that I feel strongly about and I encourage my colleagues to look for ways to curb and stop abortions in the United States, while compassionately educating on this important issue."{{cite web|last1=Baragona|first1=Justin |title=Taking Back the House, Vol. 3: Robert Aderholt and Alabama's 4th District|url=http://www.politicususa.com/2013/10/25/house-vol-3-robert-aderholt-alabamas-4th-district.html|website=PoliticalUSA|accessdate=January 25, 2017}} ===Tax policy=== Aderholt is a signer of [[Americans for Tax Reform]]'s [[Taxpayer Protection Pledge]].{{sfn|ATR|2010}} He voted in favor of the [[Tax Cuts and Jobs Act of 2017]].{{cite web|last1=Almukhtar|first1=Sarah|title=How Each House Member Voted on the Tax Bill|url=https://www.nytimes.com/interactive/2017/12/19/us/politics/tax-bill-house-live-vote.html?_r=0|website=The New York Times|accessdate=December 21, 2017|date=December 19, 2017}} Aderholt said he voted for the bill "to give back more money to Alabama taxpayers."{{cite web|last1=Hagstrom|first1=Jerry|title=Senate Passes Tax Bill Late Tuesday, But Rules Force House to Revote Wednesday|url=https://www.dtnpf.com/agriculture/web/ag/news/world-policy/article/2017/12/20/senate-passes-tax-bill-late-tuesday|website=DTN Progressive Farmer|accessdate=December 21, 2017}} He also stated that the bill "does the right thing." He cited the raising of the [[child tax credit]], changes to the state and local tax deductions, and stated that "more than 80% the people in the 4th District of Alabama will receive a tax cut." Aderholt also says that more businesses will stay in the US due to a lower corporate tax rate and therefore the act is a "jobs bill."{{cite web|title=House passes $1.5T tax bill, delivering on a major piece of GOP agenda|url=http://whnt.com/2017/12/19/house-passes-1-5t-tax-bill-delivering-on-a-major-piece-of-gop-agenda/|website=WHNT.com|accessdate=December 21, 2017|date=December 19, 2017}} ==Electoral history== {| class="wikitable" ! colspan="5" |Alabama's 4th Congressional District House Primary Election, 1996 |- !Party !Candidate !Votes !% !± |- |Republican |Robert B. {{for|the surname Kamkar|Kamkar}} {{Infobox person | name = Samy Kamkar | image = Samy Kamkar.jpg | alt = | caption = Kamkar speaking at the [[Black Hat Briefings|Black Hat conference]] in 2010. | birth_name = | birth_date = {{Birth date and age|1985|12|10|mf =yes}} | birth_place = | death_date = <!-- {{Death date and age|YYYY|MM|DD|YYYY|MM|DD}} (death date then birth date) --> | death_place = | nationality = American | other_names = | website = {{URL|http://samy.pl/|samy.pl}} | known_for = Releasing [[Samy (XSS)|the Samy worm]], [[Evercookie]], [[SkyJack]], and iPhone, [[Android (operating system)|Android]] and Windows [[Mobile phone tracking]] research | occupation = Privacy and security researcher, computer [[Hacker (term)|hacker]], whistleblower and entrepreneur }}
'''Samy Kamkar''' (born December 10, 1985)<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://twitter.com/samykamkar/status/145673083364196354|title=Twitter / samykamkar|publisher=[[Twitter]]}}</ref> is an American privacy and security researcher, [[computer hacker]], [[whistleblower]] and [[entrepreneur]]. At the age of 16, Kamkar dropped out of high school<ref name="Fusion">{{Cite web|url=http://fusion.net/story/180919/samy-kamkar-is-a-white-hat-hacking-hero/|title=Samy Kamkar got 3-year computer ban now he's a hacker hero|publisher=[[Fusion (TV channel)]]|date=September 28, 2015|accessdate=2015-09-28}}</ref> and one year later, co-founded [[www.fonality.com|Fonality]], a unified communications company based on open source software, which raised over $46 million in private funding.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.crunchbase.com/company/fonality|title=Fonality - CrunchBase Profile|publisher=[[CrunchBase]]}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web|url=https://software.intel.com/en-us/articles/open-source-fonality |title=Open Source - Fonality|publisher=[[Intel]]}}</ref> He is possibly best known for creating and releasing the fastest spreading [[Computer virus#Cross-site scripting virus|virus]] of all time,<ref name="net-security.org">{{cite web |url=http://net-security.org/dl/articles/WHXSSThreats.pdf |title=Cross-Side Scripting Worms and Viruses: The Impending Thread and the Best Defense |date=April 2006 |author=Jeremiah Grossman |publisher=Whitehat Security |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20110104191201/http://net-security.org/dl/articles/WHXSSThreats.pdf |archive-date=2011-01-04}}</ref> the [[MySpace]] worm [[Samy (XSS)|Samy]], and being subsequently raided for it by the [[United States Secret Service]], under the [[Patriot Act]].<ref name="lists.owasp.org">{{cite web|url=http://lists.owasp.org/pipermail/owasp-losangeles/2008-December/000037.html|title=[Owasp-losangeles] OWASP LA|publisher=|accessdate=25 December 2015}}</ref> He is also known for creating [[SkyJack]], a custom drone which hacks into any nearby [[Parrot AR.Drone|Parrot drones]] allowing them to be controlled by its operator,<ref name="Goodin">{{cite news | title=Flying hacker contraption hunts other drones, turns them into zombies | url=https://arstechnica.com/security/2013/12/flying-hacker-contraption-hunts-other-drones-turns-them-into-zombies/ | work=Ars Technica | first=Dan | last=Goodin | date=2013-12-08}}</ref> and for creating the [[Evercookie]], which appeared in a top-secret [[National Security Agency|NSA]] document<ref name="'Tor Stinks' presentation">{{cite news | title='Tor Stinks' presentation | work=The Guardian | url=https://www.theguardian.com/world/interactive/2013/oct/04/tor-stinks-nsa-presentation-document}}</ref> revealed by [[Edward Snowden]] and on the front page of ''[[The New York Times]]''.<ref name="The New York Times">{{Cite web|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2010/10/11/business/media/11privacy.html|title=New Web Code Draws Concern Over Privacy Risks|publisher=[[The New York Times]]|date=October 10, 2010|accessdate=2011-05-19}}</ref> He is also known for his work with ''[[The Wall Street Journal]]'' and his discovery of the illicit [[mobile phone tracking]] where the Apple [[iPhone]], Google [[Android (operating system)|Android]] and Microsoft [[Windows Phone]] mobile devices transmit GPS and Wi-Fi information to their parent companies. His mobile research led to a series of class-action lawsuits against the companies and a privacy hearing on Capitol Hill.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.cnn.com/2011/POLITICS/05/10/senate.smartphone.hearing/index.html|title=Google and Apple on Capitol Hill for high-tech privacy hearing|publisher=[[CNN]]}}</ref>
== Work ==
=== Samy worm === {{Main| Samy (computer worm)}} In 2005, Kamkar released [[Samy (XSS)|the Samy worm]], the first publicly released self-propagating cross-site scripting worm, onto [[MySpace]].<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.betanews.com/article/CrossSite-Scripting-Worm-Hits-MySpace/1129232391|title=Cross-Site Scripting Worm Hits MySpace|date=October 13, 2005|publisher=[[Betanews]]}}</ref> The worm carried a [[Payload (software)|payload]] that would display the string "but most of all, Samy is my hero" on a victim's profile and cause the victim to unknowingly send a friend request to Kamkar. When a user viewed that profile, they would have the payload planted on their page. Within just 20 hours<ref>{{cite web|url=http://namb.la/popular/tech.html|title=MySpace Worm Explanation|publisher=|accessdate=25 December 2015|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150924043923/http://namb.la/popular/tech.html|archivedate=24 September 2015|df=}}</ref> of its October 4, 2005 release, over one million users had run the payload,<ref>{{cite web|url=http://it.slashdot.org/it/05/10/14/126233.shtml?tid=172&tid=95&tid=220|publisher=[[Slashdot]]|title=Cross-Site Scripting Worm Floods MySpace}}</ref> making it the fastest spreading [[Computer virus#Cross-site scripting virus|virus]] of all time.<ref name="net-security.org"/> The MySpace team temporarily shut down MySpace to fix the problem that allowed the worm to operate.
In 2006, Kamkar was raided by the [[United States Secret Service]] and Electronic Crimes Task Force, expanded from the [[Patriot Act]], for releasing the worm.<ref name="lists.owasp.org"/> After being presented with a [[plea bargain]] for no prison time, but paying a fine of $20,000 USD, serving three years of probation, working 720 hours of community service, Kamkar pled guilty to a felony charge of computer hacking in Los Angeles Superior Court.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.techspot.com/news/24226-myspace-speaks-about-samy-kamkars-sentencing.html|title=MySpace speaks about Samy Kamkar's sentencing|work=TechSpot|access-date=2017-07-15|language=en-us}}</ref> Also per the aforementioned agreement, Kamkar was allowed to keep a single unnetworked computer, but explicitly prohibited from any internet access during his sentence.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://video.vice.com/en_us/video/samy-kamkar/56967e5eebd057947f8d0fc5|title=Greatest Moments In Hacking History: Samy Kamkar Takes Down Myspace|website=Vice-videos|language=en|access-date=2017-07-15}}</ref> Since 2008, Kamkar has been doing independent computer security and privacy research and consulting.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.wsj.com/articles/SB10001424052748703983704576277101723453610|title=Background Data|date=April 22, 2011|publisher=[[The Wall Street Journal]]}}</ref>
=== Notable works === In 2008, after Kamkar's restriction from computers was lifted, he demonstrated weaknesses in [[EMV|Visa, MasterCard and Europay]] credit cards with [[near field communication]] (NFC) and [[radio-frequency identification]] (RFID) chips built in and released software demonstrating the ability to steal credit card information, including name, credit card number, and expiration date, wirelessly from these cards.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://samy.pl/chap.py|title=chap.py}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web|url=http://rfidiot.org/documentation.html|title=RFIDiot Documentation}}</ref> He also released code demonstrating [[wireless identity theft]] of [[physical access control]] cards, including that of [[HID Global]] cards, using [[radio-frequency identification|RFID]] with the use of only a credit card sized device, removing the need for any computer to be connected.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://blog.spiderlabs.com/2012/09/getting-in-with-the-proxmark-3.html|title=SpiderLabs - Getting in with the Proxmark3}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web|url=https://code.google.com/p/proxmark3/source/detail?r=22|title=Proxmark3 Code}}</ref>
In 2010, Kamkar traveled to more than a dozen countries speaking about his mobile security research and weaknesses he discovered from his [[cryptanalysis]] of the [[PHP]] programming language, including speaking at some of the largest annual hacker conventions in the world such as [[DEF CON]], [[Black Hat Briefings]] and [[ToorCon]].<ref>{{cite web | url=http://samy.pl/tour | title=Samy Kamkar Talks | accessdate=2013-04-28}}</ref><ref>{{cite web | url=http://www.defcon.org/html/defcon-18/dc-18-speakers.html | title=DEF CON 18 Speakers | accessdate=2013-04-28}}</ref><ref>{{cite web | url=https://www.blackhat.com/html/bh-us-10/bh-us-10-speaker_bios.html | title=Black Hat USA 2010 Speakers | accessdate=2013-04-28}}</ref>
In late 2010, Kamkar traveled to [[Bratislava]] to attend [[Faraday Hack Day]] to help expose political and corporate corruption within [[Slovakia]]'s government.<ref>{{cite web | url=https://hackaday.com/tag/faraday/ | title=Faraday Hack Day | accessdate=2013-04-28}}</ref>
In early 2011, Kamkar joined the Board of Directors of [[Brave New Software]],<ref>{{cite web | url=http://www.bravenewsoftware.org | title=Brave New Software}}</ref> a non-profit organization originally funded by a multimillion-dollar [[United States Department of State|U.S. State Department]] grant.<ref>{{cite web | url=http://www.nantucketproject.com/adam-fisk | title=Brave New Software}}</ref> The nonprofit is responsible for creating [[uProxy]] with the [[University of Washington]] and [[Google Ideas]], a browser extension intended to allow users in repressive regimes to access the Internet without being monitored. The nonprofit also created [[Lantern (software)|Lantern]], a network designed to circumvent Internet censorship and defeat the suppression of digital information and freedom of speech.<ref>{{cite web | url=http://www.getlantern.org | title=Lantern}}</ref>
In addition to releasing the [[Evercookie]] as free and open source software, and exposing the surreptitious collection of data by Apple, Google and Microsoft,<ref name="Apple, Google Collect User Data">{{Cite web|url=https://www.wsj.com/articles/SB10001424052748703983704576277101723453610|title=Apple, Google Collect User Data|date=April 22, 2011|publisher=[[The Wall Street Journal]]|accessdate=2011-05-19}}</ref> in 2011 Kamkar also exposed KISSmetrics and Hulu as recreating tracking cookies after consumers deleted them by storing the unique tracking identifiers in Flash cookies and [[Web storage|HTML5 Local Storage]], which were not automatically deleted when consumers cleared their browser cookies.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://ashkansoltani.org/docs/respawn_redux.html|title=Respawn Redux by Ashkan Soltani}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web|url=http://samy.pl/research/KMResearch-SamyKamkar.pdf|title=Samy Kamkar KISSmetrics Research}}</ref> Several companies identified as performing cookie respawning were subsequently sued by class-action lawyers. In January 2013, KISSmetrics, an online advertising network, settled its cookie respawning related lawsuit for $500,000.<ref>{{cite news | url=http://www.mediapost.com/publications/article/191409/kissmetrics-finalizes-supercookies-settlement.html | title=KISSmetrics Finalizes Supercookies Settlement | accessdate=2013-01-18 | last=Davis| first=Wendy | date=2013-01-23 | work=MediaPost New}}</ref>
=== Flaw in PHP === In early 2010, Kamkar discovered a major flaw in all versions of the [[PHP]] programming language, specifically in the [[pseudorandom number generator]], which allowed an attacker to hijack the [[session ID]] of a user and take over their session.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.h-online.com/security/news/item/PHP-blunders-with-random-numbers-967525.html|title=PHP blunders with random numbers|publisher=|date=|accessdate=}}</ref> Kamkar released a patch<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://php.net/releases/5_3_2.php|title=PHP 5.3.2 Release Announcement|publisher=|date=|accessdate=}}</ref> and once fixed, released exploit code demonstrating the attack which was possible on major banks, social networks, and forums.<ref>{{cite book |last1=Baldoni |first1=Roberto |authorlink1=Roberto Baldoni|last2=Chockler |first2=Gregory |authorlink2=Gregory Chockler|year=2012 |title=Collaborative Financial Infrastructure Protection}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web|url=http://samy.pl/phpwn|title=Attack on PHP sessions and random numbers|publisher=|date=|accessdate=}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web|url=http://seclists.org/fulldisclosure/2010/Mar/519|title=Advisory: Weak RNG in PHP session ID generation leads to session hijacking|publisher=|date=|accessdate=}}</ref>
=== Evercookie === {{main|Evercookie}} In 2010, Kamkar released [[Evercookie]], a cookie that "apparently cannot be deleted", which subsequently was documented on the front page of ''[[The New York Times]]''.<ref name="The New York Times"/><ref>{{Cite web|url=http://technolog.msnbc.msn.com/_news/2010/09/22/5157641-evercookie-is-one-cookie-you-dont-want-to-bite-|title='Evercookie' is one cookie you don't want to bite|publisher=[[MSNBC]]|date=September 22, 2010|accessdate=2011-05-19}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web|url=http://threatpost.com/en_us/blogs/qa-evercookie-creator-samy-kamkar-102710|title=Q&A: Evercookie Creator Samy Kamkar}}</ref> In 2013, a top-secret [[NSA]] document was leaked<ref name="'Tor Stinks' presentation"/> by [[Edward Snowden]] citing Evercookie as a method of tracking [[Tor (anonymity network)|Tor]] users.
=== Mobile research === {{main|Mobile phone tracking}} In 2011, Kamkar discovered the iPhone, Android and Windows Phone mobile devices were continuously sending GPS coordinates, correlated to Wi-Fi MAC addresses, back to Apple, Google and Microsoft respectively, and released his research through several front page ''[[The Wall Street Journal]]'' articles.<ref name="Apple, Google Collect User Data"/><ref name="The Wall Street Journal">{{Cite web|url=https://www.wsj.com/articles/SB10001424052748703367004576288790268529716|title=Jobs Tries to Calm iPhone Imbroglio|date=April 28, 2011|publisher=[[The Wall Street Journal]]|accessdate=2011-05-19}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web|url=http://news.cnet.com/8301-31921_3-20100228-281/microsoft-collects-phone-location-data-without-permission-says-researcher/|title=Microsoft collects phone location data without permission|date=September 2, 2011|publisher=[[CNET Networks]]|accessdate=2011-05-19}}</ref> The iPhone would continue to send location data "even when the location services were turned off".<ref name="The Wall Street Journal"/> The Windows Phone would also continue to send location data "even when the user has not given the app permission to do so". He discovered that some of this data was exposed by Google and he released [http://samy.pl/androidmap/ Androidmap], a tool exposing Google's database of Wi-Fi MAC addresses correlated to the physical coordinates populated by Android phones.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.huffingtonpost.com/2011/04/25/android-map-reveals-router-location_n_853214.html|title=Google's Wi-Fi Database May Know Your Router's Physical Location|publisher=[[Huffington Post]]|date=April 25, 2011|accessdate=2011-05-19}}</ref>
=== Parrot AR Drone research === {{main|SkyJack}} In 2013, Kamkar created [[SkyJack]], a combination of open source software and hardware to run on an [[unmanned aerial vehicle]] which was "engineered to autonomously seek out, hack, and wirelessly take over other [[Parrot AR.Drone|Parrot drones]] within wifi distance, creating an army of zombie drones".<ref name="Goodin"/><ref name="samy">{{cite web | title=Samy Kamkar - SkyJack | url=http://www.samy.pl/skyjack}}</ref> The entire software and hardware specification was released as open source and detailed on his website.<ref name="samy"/><ref>{{cite web | title=SkyJack source code | url=https://github.com/samyk/skyjack/commits/master| date=2013-12-08 | accessdate=2013-12-08 }}</ref> The software was released one day after [[Amazon.com]] announced [[Amazon.com#Amazon Prime Air|Amazon Prime Air]], a possible future delivery service using drones to deliver small packages in as early as 2015.<ref name=Mash>{{cite web|last=Strange|first=Adario|title=Amazon Unveils Flying Delivery Drones on '60 Minutes'|url=http://mashable.com/2013/12/01/amazon-unveils-flying-robot-delivery-drones/|work=Mashable|accessdate=2013-12-01}}</ref>
=== Automotive security research ===
On July 30, 2015, Kamkar introduced OwnStar - a small electronic device that could be concealed on or near a [[General Motors]] vehicle to interpose itself between the vehicle's [[OnStar]] link and the driver's OnStar RemoteLink [[Mobile app|app]]. In this classic [[man-in-the-middle]] attack, Kamkar, or any unauthorized user, could substitute his OnStar commands to locate, unlock, or start the vehicle. By August 11, General Motors had released upgrades to the OnStar server software and RemoteLink app to block such attacks.<ref name="AutoNet">{{cite news | title=OnStar Plugs Hacker Attacks | url=http://www.theautonet.com/en/2015/08/11/onstar-plugs-hacker-attacks | work=[[Autonet]] | first=Glen | last=Woodcock | date=2015-08-11 | accessdate=2015-08-11}}</ref>
In 2015, it was reported that Kamkar had built an inexpensive electronic device about the size of a wallet that could be concealed on or near a locked vehicle to capture a single [[keyless entry]] code to be used at a later time to unlock the vehicle. The device transmits a jamming signal to block the vehicle's reception of [[rolling code]] signals from the owner's fob, while recording these signals from both of his two attempts needed to unlock the vehicle. The recorded first code is sent to the vehicle only when the owner makes the second attempt, while the recorded second code is retained for future use. Kamkar stated that this vulnerability had been widely known for years to be present in many vehicle types, but was previously undemonstrated.<ref name="RollinCode">{{cite news | title=A hacker made a $30 gadget that can unlock many cars that have keyless entry | url=http://www.techinsider.io/samy-kamkar-keyless-entry-car-hack-2015-8 | work=[[Tech Insider]] | first=Cadie | last=Thompson | date=2015-08-06 | accessdate=2015-08-11}}</ref> A demonstration was announced for [[DEF CON]] 23.<ref name="DC23">{{cite web | title=Drive It Like You Hacked It: New Attacks and Tools to Wirelessly Steal Cars | url=https://www.defcon.org/html/defcon-23/dc-23-speakers.html#Kamkar | work=[[DEF CON]] 23 | first=Samy | last=Kamkar | date=2015-08-07 | accessdate=2015-08-11}}</ref>
=== Magnetic stripe and credit card emulation device ===
On November 24, 2015, Samy Kamkar released MagSpoof;<ref>{{cite web|url=https://github.com/samyk/magspoof|title=samyk/magspoof|work=GitHub|accessdate=25 December 2015}}</ref> a portable device that can spoof/emulate any magnetic stripe or credit card "wirelessly", even on standard magstripe readers by generating a strong electromagnetic field that emulates a traditional magnetic stripe card.
In his own words, MagSpoof can be used as a traditional credit card and simply store all of your credit cards (and with modification, can technically disable chip requirements) in various form factors, or can be used for security research in any area that would traditionally require a magstripe, such as readers for credit cards, drivers licenses, hotel room keys, automated parking lot tickets, etc.
=== Internet traffic hijacking ===
On November 16, 2016, Samy Kamkar released PoisonTap;<ref>{{cite web|url=https://github.com/samyk/poisontap|title=samyk/poisontap|work=GitHub|accessdate=16 November 2016}}</ref> a USB ethernet emulator that can be used to hijack all Internet traffic on a target machine, even if the computer was password protected and locked.
A backdoored device can be remotely forced to make a request with its user's cookies on http websites that have no security flags, meaning that the attacker can remotely impersonate a local user.

'''Susan Marie Gerbic''' (born August 8, 1962) is an American [[scientific skepticism|skeptical activist]] living in [[Salinas, California]].<ref name=californian>{{cite news|last=Nordstrand|first=Dave|title=Staying on the job during cancer treatment|url=http://www.thecalifornian.com/story/life/2014/07/05/staying-job-cancer-treatment/12202333/|work=The Californian|publisher=Gannett|date=July 5, 2014|department=Life|location=Salinas, California|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150830002956/http://www.thecalifornian.com/story/life/2014/07/05/staying-job-cancer-treatment/12202333/?from=global&sessionKey=&autologin=|archivedate=August 30, 2015|deadurl=no|accessdate=August 29, 2015}}</ref> Gerbic is the co-founder of Monterey County Skeptics,<ref name="mcsmeetup">{{cite web|url=http://www.meetup.com/Monterey-County-Skeptics/|title=Monterey County Skeptics|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150830012113/http://www.meetup.com/Monterey-County-Skeptics/|archivedate=August 30, 2015|deadurl=no|accessdate=August 29, 2015}}</ref> founder of Skeptic Action, founder and leader of the Guerrilla Skepticism on Wikipedia (GSoW) project,<ref name="csicop395">{{cite journal|title=Is Wikipedia a Conspiracy? Common Myths Explained|url=http://www.csicop.org/si/show/is_wikipedia_a_conspiracy_common_myths_explained|work=[[Skeptical Inquirer]]|publisher=[[Committee for Skeptical Inquiry]]|first=Susan|last=Gerbic|date=September 2015|series=39|volume=5|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20161011171044/http://www.csicop.org/si/show/is_wikipedia_a_conspiracy_common_myths_explained|archivedate=October 11, 2016|deadurl=no|accessdate=February 28, 2017}}</ref> a recurring contributor to the ''[[Skepticality]]'' podcast, a regular contributor to ''[[Skeptical Inquirer]]'',<ref>{{cite web|title=Articles by Susan Gerbic|url=http://www.csicop.org/author/susan_gerbic|work=[[Skeptical Inquirer]]|publisher=[[Committee for Skeptical Inquiry]]|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150830005208/http://www.csicop.org/author/susan_gerbic|archivedate=August 30, 2015|deadurl=no|accessdate=August 29, 2015}},</ref> and a [[fellow]] of the [[Committee for Skeptical Inquiry]].<ref name="csifellow"/> Gerbic has focused much of her skeptical activism on people claiming to be "[[clairvoyant]] [[Mediumship|mediums]]", such as [[Sylvia Brown]] and [[Tyler Henry]], whom she calls "Grief Vampires".<ref name = "GVs"/> {{toclimit|limit=3}} <!-- This code controls max depth of TOC.-->
== Skepticism == Gerbic's interest in paranormal and fringe topics began during childhood, when she was most frightened by [[spontaneous human combustion]], "the idea that you could be walking down the street and suddenly, BOOM!"<ref name="2nd bday">{{cite AV media|last=Gerbic|first=Susan|title=GSoW 2nd Bday video|url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=efU-2yw0U58|work=[[YouTube]]|date=June 8, 2013|type=Motion picture|accessdate=August 29, 2015|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160312230038/https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=efU-2yw0U58|archivedate=March 12, 2016|df=mdy-all}}{{plays audio}}</ref> She grew up in Salinas as a [[Southern Baptist Convention|Southern Baptist]] who became interested in [[scientific skepticism|skepticism]] in the 1990s.<ref name="skeptchal">{{Cite podcast|url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=iUCwKG1n9zc|title=Skeptically Challenged 2014/06/19|last1=Balch|first1=Ross|work=Skeptically Challenged|date=June 19, 2014|accessdate=August 29, 2015|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160309230832/https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=iUCwKG1n9zc|archivedate=March 9, 2016|df=mdy-all}}{{plays audio}}</ref> "I had never heard the word atheist until I was in my late teens," Gerbic told Skeptical Inquirer editor [[Benjamin Radford]]. "Once I found out there were other people who felt the way I did, I read everything I could on the subject". In 2000, Gerbic discovered that there was a community of skeptics and went to her first conference, [[Skeptic's Toolbox]] in Eugene, Oregon a month later. "I felt like I had found my people."<ref name="Radford">{{cite journal|last1=Radford|first1=Ben|authorlink= Benjamin Radford|title=Skepticism One Wikipage at a Time: Talking with Wikiskeptic Susan Gerbic-Forsyth|journal=Skeptical Inquirer|date=March 2012|volume=36|issue=2|pages=32–33|subscription=yes}}{{verify source|date=August 2015}}<!-- I have no access --></ref>
In a 2017 article she wrote for ''[[Skeptical Inquirer]]'' magazine, "How I Got Hooked on the Skeptical World," Gerbic related how her transformation into a [[scientific skeptic]] began after finding ''Skeptical Inquirer'' saying: {{quote|text=When I discovered Skeptical Inquirer magazine in 1996, it was eye-opening. I believe the first issue I picked up was the January/February “Star Cradle” one. My subscription began with the September/October 1997 issue. Inside I found answers to lots of questions—about ghosts, psychics, Bigfoot, all that fascinated me. I learned about things I had never thought of, and upon reading some articles I thought, “People believe that?” Other articles made me say, “Wait, that isn’t real?”<ref>{{cite web|last1=Gerbic|first1=Susan|title=How I Got Hooked on the Skeptical World|url=http://www.csicop.org/si/show/how_i_got_hooked_on_the_skeptical_world|website=CSICOP.org|publisher=Center for Inquiry|accessdate=3 March 2017|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20170302160438/http://www.csicop.org/si/show/how_i_got_hooked_on_the_skeptical_world|archivedate=March 2, 2017|df=mdy-all}}</ref>}}
In February 2018, The [[Center For Inquiry]] announced that Gerbic had been appointed a [[fellow]], stating that "CSI fellows are elected for their distinguished service to science and skepticism, serving as advisers to CSI and its magazine, ''Skeptical Inquirer'', and are invited to share their expertise and advice on the program’s issues and projects."<ref name="csifellow">{{Cite web|url=http://www.centerforinquiry.net/news/cause_effect_99/|title=Center for Inquiry News: Cause & Effect: The CFI Newsletter - No. 99|website=www.centerforinquiry.net|language=en|access-date=2018-02-07|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20180208134003/http://www.centerforinquiry.net/news/cause_effect_99/|archivedate=8 February 2018|deadurl=no}}</ref> Prior to this appointment, Gerbic served as a scientific and technical consultant for the [[Committee for Skeptical Inquiry]].<ref>{{cite web | url=http://www.csicop.org/si/show/ten_distinguished_scientists_and_scholars_named_fellows_of_committee_for_sk | title=Ten Distinguished Scientists and Scholars Named Fellows of Committee for Skeptical Inquiry | publisher=Center for Inquiry | work=Skeptical Inquirer | accessdate=13 October 2015 | deadurl=no | archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20151016122711/http://www.csicop.org/si/show/ten_distinguished_scientists_and_scholars_named_fellows_of_committee_for_sk | archivedate=October 16, 2015 | df=mdy-all }}</ref>
